editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE ILE OF GVLLS.
As it hath been often Acted in the Black Fryers, by the Children of the REVELS.
LONDON, Printed for WILLIAM SHEARES, at the Harrow in Britaines Burſſe. 1633.

div.head: THE ILE OF GVLLS.
div.stage: I Enter ſeverally three Gentlemen, as to ſee a Play.

sp.p: HOW now gallants, what iſt? what iſt?
The Ile of Guls.
The Ile of Guls, what ſhould that be?
A play by the name, but come ſhals quarter our ſelues?
If ſome had had the wit to doe ſo in time, they might haue ſau'd the hang-man a labour. But come boy, furniſh us with ſtooles.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Pardon mee ſir, my office is to ſpeake a Prologue, not to provide you ſtooles.
And you were the Epilogue to ſir—
Fie be not incivill: doſt heare youth, prethee what's he that diſcovered your new found Land, the Ile of Guls? what is he?

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: A meere ſtranger ſir.
A ſtranger? the better welcome: comes hee Eaſt-ward, Weſt-ward, or North-ward hoe?

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: None of the three wayes I aſſure you.
Prethee where is he?

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Not on his knees in a comer to Apollo, praying that his play may hold in a good hand at Paſſage, nor on the ſtage amongſt gallants, preparing a beſpoke Plaudite; but cloſe in his ſtudy writing hard, to get him a handſome ſuite againſt Summer.
And where ſit his friends? hath he not a prepared company of gallants, to applaud his jeſts, and grace out his play?

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: None I proteſt▪ Do Poets uſe to beſpeake their Auditory?
The beſt in grace doe, and but for that, ſome that I know, had never had their grace in Poetry till this day.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Then muſt our Author looké for a certaine diſgrace, for he is altogether unfurniſht of ſuch a friendly audience.

Then he muſt lay his triall upon God and good wits But why
doth he call his play The Ile of Gulls? it begets much expectation.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Not out of any dogged diſpoſition, nor that it figures any certaine ſtate, or private government: farre bee that ſuppoſition from the thought of any indifferent Auditor: and the argument being a little ſtring or • ivolet, drawen from the full ſtraine of the right worthy Gentleman Sir Phillip Sydnies well knowne Arcadia, confirmes it: only a Duke, to make triall of certaine experiments, retires with his retinue into a nameleſſe deſert. Now as well for faſhion ſake, as that all thoſe which haue to doe in that deſert, are guld in the reach of their hopes; therefore he cals it, (and as he preſumes, not improperly) The Ile of Gulls.

Out a queſtion he hath promiſed thee ſome fee, thou pleadeſt ſo hard for him, but and he be a right Poet he will never performe it. But what method obſerues he in his Play, iſt any thing Criticall? Are Lawyers fees, and Citizens wiues laid open in it? I loue to heare vice anatomizd, and abuſe let blood in the maſter vaine, is there any great mans life charactred in't?

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: None I proteſt ſir, only in the perſon of Dametas, he expreſſes to the life the monſtrous and deformed ſhape of vice, aſwell to beget a loathing of abuſe, as that his villany may giue the greater luſter to the vertuous diſpoſitions of true-borne gentility.
All that's nothing to mee, and there bee not Worme-wood water and Copperes in't, Ile not like it, ſhould Apollo write it, and Roſius himſelfe act it.

Fie upon thee, thou art too too criticall: is there any good baudry in't, jeſts of an ell deepe, and a fathome broad, good cuckolding, may a couple of young-ſetters-up learne to doe well in't? Giue me a Scene of venery, that will make a mans ſpirits ſtand on their tiptoes, and die his blood in a deepe ſcarlet, like your Ovids Ars Amandi, there flowes the true Spring-head of Poetry, and the very Chriſtall fount of Parnaſſus.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Chaſt eares would never endure it fir.
Chaſt eares? now deafeneſſe light upon them, what ſhould chaſt eares doe at a play?
Tis ſtrange now, I am of neither a both your opinions, I like neither rayling nor baudry: no, giue me a ſtately pend hiſtorie, as thus: The rugged winds, with rude and ragged ruffes, &c.
Fie upon't, more fuſtian; I had rather heare two good baudy jeſts, then a whole play of ſuch teare-cat thunder-claps.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Alas Gentlemen, bow iſt poſſible to content you? you wil haue rayling, and invectiues, which our Author neither dares, nor affects: you baudy and ſcurrill jeſts, which neither becomes his modeſty to write, nor the eare of a generous Auditory to heare: you muſt haue ſwelling compariſons, and • um • aſt Epithites, which are as fit for the body of a Com • edy▪ as Her •• les ſhooe for the foote of a Pigmey: yet all theſe we muſt haue, and all in one play, or tis already condemn'd to the hell of eternall diſgrace.
Looke to't, if there be not gall in't, it ſhall not paſſe.
If it be not baudy, tis impoſſible to paſſe:
If it bee both criticall and baudy, if it bee not high written, both your Poet and the houſe too, looſe a friend of me.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Nay I beſeech you ſir, if you be his friend, ſtand ſo to him ſtill, for he hath too many enemies already, in whoſe judgements, he and his labours ſtand excommunicate, as though unworthy to preſent themſelues in this aſſembly.
Enemies? nays foote then there's ſome hope in his play, for Envie never workes but againſt deſert and merit. If he be envied theres ſome worth in him, and ile ſee out his play for that onely.
Faith and Ile ſee an act or two out, but I tell you afore-hand I cannot ſee it out.
Not ſee it out? your reaſon.
Fore God I lay in bed till paſt three a clock, ſlept out my dinner, and my ſtomacke will toule to ſupper afore fiue, therefore you muſt pardon me.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Either ſee it all or none; for tis growen into a cuſtome at playes, if any one riſe (eſpecially of any faſhionable ſort) about what ſerious buſines ſoever, the reſt thinking it in diſlike of the play, though he never thinks it, cry mew, by • eſus vilde; and leaue the poore heartleſſe children to ſpeake their Epilogue to the empty ſeats.
Why doeſt thinke thy audience like a flock of ſheepe, that one cannot leape over a hedge, but all the reſt will follow? they haue more of reaſon in them then ſo.
Well, Ile ſit out the play, an't bee but to avoyd that ſheepiſh imputation, but ſee it be baudy, or by this light I and all my friends will hiſſe.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: You ſhould not deale gentleman-like with us els.

div.head: Prologus.
div.l: THe miſery that waytes upon the pen
Of the beſt Writers, iudge it Gentlemen,
Let them expreſſe the very ſoule of wit,
And want Opinions voice to count'nance it,
Tis like the idle buzzing of a Flie,
Heard, not regarded: wretched Poetry!
If he write mirth, tis ribaldry, and meane,
Scorn'd of chaſt eares: If he compoſe a Sceane
Of high writ Poeſie, fitting a true ſtage,
Tis counted ſuſtian: If Poetickerage
Strike at abuſe, or op • the veine of ſinne,
Hee's ſtraight inform'd againſt for libelling.
Neither quicke mirth, invective, nor high ſtate
Can content all, ſuch is the boundleſſe hate
Of a confuſed Audience: Then we
That ſcarcely know the rules of Poeſie
Cannot ſcape check. Yet this our comfort is,
The wiſe will ſmile to heare th'impartiall hiſſe.
We neither bragge, nor tremble, faint nor intreat,
Our merits nothing, yet our hopes are great,
Yet this our Author bad me boldly ſpeake,
His play ſhall paſſe, let Envie ſwell and breake,
Detraction he ſcornes, honours the beſt,
Tanti for hate; thus low to all the reſt.

div.head: ACTVS. I. SCENA. I.

stage.p: Enter Baſilius, Gynetia, Hipolita, Violetta, Lords attendants.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: VVElcome gallants, welcome honor'd bloods; the reaſon that we haue uncloth'd us of our princely government in Arcadia, and haue to doe with this private retirement here in this deſert Ile, you ſhall find in that ſhedule, only thus much for publicke ſatisfaction: Tis not ſtrange to you, that the choiſeſt treaſure Nature indow'd us with, is min'd up in the veines of my two daughters: how much their quiet, and the ſmooth ſtreame of our government in Arcadia, was troubled by the impetuous concourſe of untruely ſuters, is familiar with your knowledge; this to avoid, I haue for my Image there in my abſence appointed my brother, and undertooke this private retirement.

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.p: Why my Lord, are you ſo covetous of your daughters beauties, that their perfections ſhall bee a meanes to hinder their preferment?

sp.speaker: Baſi.
sp.p: Rather to further it faire Queene: they are the only pearles of our age, and to ſee them wel ſet in honourable and well-befitting Marriage, is our wiſhes happineſſe.
sp.l: To which effect we haue ſent a generall challenge
To all the youthfull bloods of Affrica,
Dares foote the boſome of this deſert Ile,
(The ſtage where Ile performe this lovers prize)
And by his wit and actiue pollicie,
Wooe, win, intice, or any way defeate
Me of my charge, my daughters of their hearts,
Shall with their loues weare my imperiall crowne

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: A prize, a prize, rare worke for Fencers.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: What coward would not venter a crackt crowne for ſuch a bootie?

lg.l: To that intent our Iland is fenc't in
By ſea and land, and at each corner built
A Caſtle for defence, which like great men,
Doe over-looke Arcadia: over which,
Wee haue appointed Captaines. More to deſire,
Is more then we are willing to diſcover.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Well then ſiſter, I ſee we muſt to hap-hazard for husbands.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: God ſend me one with a good face and I care not.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Loue an't be thy will, ſend me one with a faire table in his forehead, like Time.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Nay, and his face be good, let me alone to tricke his forehead, a countrey-gentlewoman taught me how: But father I wonder how you dare undertake ſuch a peremptory challenge againſt all commers, conſidering you haue beene ſo long troubled with •• Ague.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: An ague? what ague?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Why your quotidian, Dametas the Court ſurfet, hee that dwels in your eye, like a diſeaſe in your blood.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: And the Preſence were not exceeding empty-ſtomackt, it would never diſgeſt ſuch Almes-basket-ſcraps, the very fall and garbidge of gentry; fie upon him, hee becomes the great chamber worſe then a Gentleman-uſher with wry legges.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: He is the moſt miſhapen ſute of gentility that ever the Court wore.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Had hee not beene of my fathers owne making, I ſhould haue condemned his taylor for an exceeding botcher.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: If you retaine the loue of children, or the dutie of ſubjects, expreſſe it in your obedience, we know Dametas loues us▪

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: As Captaines and Courtiers doe old widdowes, for profit and preferment.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: In ſigne whereof wee make him.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Nay, you haue beſtowed too much of the making of him up already.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: The very making of him up, has ſtood you in more then the whole outſide's worth.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: In my free thoughts you wrong him, therefore to expreſſe our loue, aud to giue the world publicke note of his loyaltie, we create him your Gardian.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: How father, my Gardian?

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: I minion, yours.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Doe you heare father, bid him beſpeake ſpectacles, for my fingers haue vowed to haue a blind match with his eyes.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p:
Well ſaid Haggart, Ile make your proud heart ſtoope to the lure of obedience. But come, by this time our challenge is publiſht,
and our gallants wits ſweating in the field of Invention, and it behoues us not to reſt unexerciſed.

lg.l: So to our lodge, in the meane time be it knowne,
Our breath has power to raiſe, or caſt men downe.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: Now Captaine Obſervation, times bawd, thou that haſt kept the Ages doore, whilſt up-ſtart baſeneſſe crept into the bed of greatneſſe, what doeſt thou thinke of this change?

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: That it pleas'd the Duke, and becomes not ſubjects to examine his actions.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: Thats no part of my meaning, yet would I gladly bee better inſtructed why the Duke broke up his Court in Arcadia, and removed it into this Iland.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: I am not Secretary to his thoughts, but the generall rumour is, that out of the freeneſſe of his ſpirit, he hath ſent a challenge to all his neighbour Princes, that whoſoever (within a twelue moneth) can defeate him of his daughters, ſhall with their loues enioy his Dukedome, the garland propos'd for the victors.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: Your words throw ſenſe into me, and thats the cauſe the Iland is ſo ſurely guarded with Watch-towers, over which our ſelues and other Captaines haue the charge.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: And to the end that not affection, but deſert may proue victor, are the two Ladies ſo narrowly obſerved, the one never out a the eye of her Father, the other continually in the lodge of Dametas, the Dukes chiefe director.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: If inquiſitiueneſſe be not too bold a gueſt, what do you thinke of Dametas?

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: As of a little hillock, made great with others ruines.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: Your compariſon holds, for by report, his avarice has unmade many to make him up.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: How did he firſt ſtumble on the Princes favour?

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: As ſome doe upon offices, by fortune and flattery, or as truth ſayes, the Prince having one day loſt his way, wandring in the woods, found this Dametas, affected his diſcourſe, tooke him along to the Court, and like great men in loue with their owne doings, countenanc't his defects, gaue him offices, titles, and all the additions that goe to the making up of a man worſhipfull.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p:
I cannot commend the Duke for raiſing him, nor yet
praiſe him, that hee proportions not his carriage anſwerable to his fortunes.

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.p: Your thoughts and mine are twinnes in that: but I heare the warning bell, ſome ſtrangers are arrived.

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.p: Lets to our office then, and conduct them to Dametas, whoſe cuſtome is to ſpit and hem, whilſt his Scribe Major takes their Examinations.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Manaſſes, how doeſt like my play at Tennis?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You play well, but you loſe ſtill.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Pollicie Manaſſes, pollicie; for when any man upbraides me with my gettings at Court, I may ſweare truly, I haue loſt more then I haue got by't.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: By the Tennis-court I thinke you haue.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: If by any Court, tis enough to ſaue mine oath. But what doe our ſpruce-witted gallants ſay of my bountie?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Faith ſir, according to the proportion of it, little or nothing, they ſay tis a banckrout, and dares not ſhew his head.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Then let em leaue jeſting at me, though it pleaſe the Duke for ſome few good parts that hee ſees in me, to make me his familiar, I ſcorne to be publike, or every Courtiers companion: but who comes heere?

div.stage: Enter the two Captaines, with Aminter and Iulio, two princes, one attired like a poore ſouldier, the other like a poore ſcholler.
div.p: The Captaines of the watch-towers? what newes with you?

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.p: A couple of petitioners, ant like your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Had I beſt take their Petitions, Manaſſes?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: O in any caſe, though you never peruſe em, tis the onely courſe in requeſt.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Fellowes, deliver your petitions to my Scribe Major, and doſt heare? put em up Manaſſes, they may be wrongs to us.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And they bee, I hope they be not the firſt wrongs I haue put up for your worſhip.

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.p: That fellowes pocket is like a Tailors hell, it eats up part of every mans due: tis an Executioner, and makes away more innocent petitions in one yeere, then a red-headed hangman cuts ropes in an age.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Now, what are you ſirra?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: A poore ſouldier, ant like your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Poore ſouldiers doe not like my vvorſhip, they are bad members.

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: Then if they had a woman to their Iudge, they ſhould be ſure to be cut off, for they cannot indure bad members in a Common-wealth.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What are you?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: A poore ſcholler, ant like your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Poore ſchollers do not like our worſhip neither, they raile againſt rich Cormorants, they are bad members too.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Cut them off both ſir, and make the land an Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Ile take order with em I warrant thee; and I may haue my will, ile neither ha poore ſcholler nor ſouldier about the Court.

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.p: The next way to make it the Ile of fooles.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Whats he talks of fooles there? why how now ſir, know you to whom you ſpeake?

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.p: Cry your worſhip mercy, I had forgot your authority.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: But I remember well enough I warrant you; I command you in my name and the Dukes, to attend your guard, and you regard me no more then a careleſſe Lawyer doth an undone clyent, but ile informe: the Duke ſhall know, out, packe.

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.p: Command your ſlaues ſir, we are gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Why ſo I hope are we ſir, and of the beſt and laſt edition, of the Dukes owne making.

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.p: Cry your authoritie mercy, will you diſcharge us of theſe paſſengers?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: You are diſcharg'd, about your buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.p: Bad fate, that wrong ſhould ſet his foot on right, And true borne Eagles ſtoope to this baſe Kite.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What an excellent trade it is to be an officer maker, ile haue more officers, and one ſhalbe to keepe ſchollers and ſouldiers out of the Court, for they dare not come in the great Chamber already, for want of good clothes. But gods me Manaſſes, go tell the Duke I muſt ſpeake with him.

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: Preſently ſir, Ile goe fetch the head to giue the foot a poſſet: and my maſter had wit to his villanie, he would make an excellent diſh for the hang-man.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Right vvorſhipfull.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p:
I ſir, I know my place is vvorſhipfull; I tell thee Knaue, I
could hang thee by my pattent, if it were granted once, ile tell thee how it runs, it allowes me 24. knaues, 6 knights, 10. fooles, 13. fellons, and 14. traytors by the yeare, take them how, why, when, and where I pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: I doe not thinke the Duke will ever grant it.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Why not grant it? why ſhould you thinke hee will not grant it? Such another word and ile ſend you to Limbo inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: We thanke you good Dametas. Diſcover themſelues.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: I hope you'l take reaſonable baile for our forth comming.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: The caſe is alter'd with you ſince you came out of Arcadia.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: My honorable friends, Iulio and Aminter, my ſelfe and the beſt abilitie of my power, lies at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: You ſee how confidently wee preſume upon your Letters promiſe, in furthering us to attaine the lovers prize.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: The Dukes daughters are your owne, and in a word thus ſhall you attaine them, ſome 3 dayes hence I will appoint a hunting, to which I will invite the Duke & both his daughters: in this hunt will I upon ſome ſudden occaſion divide the traine, and having ſingled out the two Does, I hope you haue wit enough to ſtrike.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: To ſtrike, how meane you?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: As headſmen doe, off with their maiden-heads, or if the Duke offer reſiſtance, off with his crowne too.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: That were violence, and cleane oppoſite to the intent of the challenge.

sp.speaker: Damet.
sp.p: Come yee are ſhallow, to't vi & armis, to't, Ile bee your ſecond, thinke of the Crowne, haue my Letters travaild for you, my wit wrought for you, and my invention ſweat for you, to poſſeſſe you of your loues, and ſeate you in the Dukedome, and come you now with tis violence, and againſt the intent of the challenge? I am aſhamed to heare you.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Nay Dametas, and your reſolution bee ſo forward, ours ſhall over-take you, wee doubted leaſt the preferments your Lord hath heapt upon you, had ſmothered your affection to usward.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: That was the father that begot the doubt in us, you will appoint the hunt.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Sever the Duke, divide the traine, and then—

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: We haue your meaning.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p:
Put it in execution then, but firſt entertaine ſome new
diſguiſe, as at our next meeting Ile informe you. Adew, I ſhall thinke long till I ſee you againe.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: As a Lawyer doth for his Clyent for a ſecond fee. Here's no Iudas?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Yes, and a damn'd one too, for he would betray and ſell his Maſter.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Tis common in ſuch baſe fellowes, ſuch Court-ſpiders, that weaue their webs of flattery in the eares of greatneſſe, if they can once entangle them in their quaint-treachery, they poyſon them ſtraight.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: They are like unneceſſary wormes, whom the ſun of greatneſſe creates of the groſſe and ſlimy multitude, as ſoone as they recover ſtrength, they eate into the credite of true borne gentry, undermine and worke out the true nobilitie, to inroote and eſtabliſh themſelues.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: And in the end, like Eſops ſtaru'd ſnake, having lapt the ſweet milk of greatneſſe, made themſelues ſtrong in authority and friends, they turne their ſtings of envie into their preſervers boſome.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: The example liues in this Dametas, who notwithſtanding the Duke hath raiſd him to that height that he lookes equall with himſelfe, yet for the baſe hope of incertaine government, he offers him to ſale; but let his treaſon liue to the laſt minute.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: For my part Ile make that uſe of him that Phyſicians doe of poyſon, uſe as much of him as ſerues for mine honeſt intent, and caſt downe the reſt, as unfit for any neceſſary imployment.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Let our carriage in this attempt put on no ſhew of violence, either to the Duke, or his daughters.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: And let our diſcourſe goe ſo ſmoothly apparelled, that it mooue not the patience of the moſt tender eare.

lg.l: About it then, though his intent be baſe,
Our enterpriſe ſhall weare a noble face.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Arcadia, thou heaven, within whoſe ſpheare

lg.l: The ſtarre that guides my motion is fixt,
I court thy gracious boſome with a kiſſe
For this admittance: in thine amorous armes,
Faire Violetta, fairer then the flower
That chriſtned her, and grac't her with that name,
Do's play the wanton:
Onely her Father like a covetous churle,
Owner of that vnvalewed Diamond,
Hath made this deſart Ile th'unwilling cheſt
In which he lockes her. But the faire advantage
Of this large Challenge, and my ſtarres to friend,
Ayded by this diſguiſe, I ſhall breake ope
His yron Casket, and inlarge my hope.

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: This way ſhe went ſir, this way.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: But I ſay this way, I would thou ſhouldſt know, we old Courtiers can hunt a Cony, and put her to the ſqueak, and make her crie out like a yong married wife of the firſt night.

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: For more helpe, as ſome of them haue done: But there ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Ile upon her preſently: doſt heare me ſirra? thou veſſell of infirmitie, woman, and by thy out-ſide little better then one of the wicked, come hither and ſhew thy ſelfe before us, ſhew thy ſelfe before Dametas.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Dametas? Liſander then diſſemble,
For hee's the man muſt worke thy entrance.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What art thou? ſpeake.

lg.l: My mother is the Queene of Amazons,
My ſelfe a Virgin, married unto Armes,
And bold atchieuements, who haue pac'd the world
In queſt of fayre Antioſte my ſiſter:
And turning homeward, the unconſtant winds,
And wrathfull Neptune caſt me on this ſhore.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: And what's your buſineſſe now you are landed?

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: My buſineſſe is in private with the Duke.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: The Duke is buſie, and ſhall ſpeake with no body.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: I beſeech you ſir.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Tis no beſeeching matter I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: No, never beſeech for the matter, for except you could beſeech with the tongue of Angels, tis to no purpoſe with him.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Tis ſtrange, I haue heard thy maſter is a very good man where hee takes.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: True, where he takes he is, but he takes nothing of you, and therefore looke for no kindneſſe from him.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Good, and doſt thou take after thy Maſter?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No Madam, I take commonly afore my Maſter, for where he takes, he takes all, and leaues nothing for me to take.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Oh, I feele your meaning.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Let my maſter haue ſome feeling of yours, and heele preferre your ſuit.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Tis not the Dukes pleaſure Petitioners ſhould buy their acceſſe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: All's one, tis my maſters pleaſure, and uſuall faſhion.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: And I muſt maintaine the faſhion. Worſhipfull Dametas, my late ſhipwrack as you ſee, hath made a defeat both of my friends and treaſure; notwithſtanding, Fortune hath referv'd me one jewell, which if I might requeſt your Worſhip in loue to accept, and be a meanes to worke my admittance to the Duke, I ſhould become a true debter to your loue.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Well Madam, tho I hate nothing more then a man that takes bribes, yet preſt by your importunity, and that you tender it in loue, leſt I might ſeeme too nice to withſtand a Ladies favour, Ile weare it for your ſake, and if the Duke be not too buſily employed, worke your acceſſe.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: So doing, you ſhall performe the office of a deare-bought friend.

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: How quickly the tide's turn'd! but doe you heare Madam? though I take neither afore nor after my Maſter, yet take my counſell, and do not truſt my maſter: if you haue a ſute to the Duke, keepe it to your ſelfe, for if you truſt my maſter with it, heele preferre it for you, but heele beg't for himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Thats plaine coozenage.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Fie no, tis cunning in him, marry twould be thought little better then coozenage in a country gentleman: but he returnes.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Madam, I haue been earneſt, very earneſt with the Duke for your admittance.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: And haue you wrought it?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I haue, marry you muſt think I beſtowd much labour in't.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: 'Tmay be you did.

sp.speaker: Dam,
sp.p: 'Tmay be you did: and looke a ſcance like a Pothecaries wife pounding Colliquintida; haue my braines ſweat for this?

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Why the jewell is right Dametas, had I but an Aſſe that would ſweat me ſuch pearle.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: An Aſſe? and ſweat ſuch pearle? Ile bar her admittance, here take your jewell, the Duke will allow no admittance, and I will keep you backe.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Keep me backe? thou couldſt doe no more and I were a poore mans petitioner.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: And Ile doe ſo much being a rich petitioner.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: You cannot ſit, you Court ſpaniell, you unneceſſary muſhrump, that in one night art ſprung out of the root of greatneſſe, I have bought my admittance, and Ile ha't in deſpetto del fato.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: I muſt admit her, theſe Ladies are ſo inward with our trickes, there's no good to be done upon them: well Madam, your admittance is open, will you follow?

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: With all my heart ſir, Ile be the blind man and poore petitioner, and thou ſhalt play the Court-ſpaniell with the ſilver bell, and lead me into the Preſence.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Court-ſpaniell? mum: Ile boſome what I thinke, Old Gib's not blind, I ſee, although I winke.

div.head: ACTVS II. SCENA I.
div.stage: Enter Demetrias a Prince attired like a Wood-man, with him his Page.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: BOy, how doſt like me in this attire?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: As the Audience doth a bad play, ſcurvily.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Is it not ſtrange a Prince ſhould be thus metamorphoſed?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Not ſo ſtrange as the Metamorphoſis of Ajax, an't like your Grace.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Grace you Aggot, haſt not forgot that yet?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: No, and yet tis a wonder I ha not, grace being ſo ſeldome uſed, I'm ſure they ſay none at ſome Ordinaries, for at ſitting down they cannot intend it for hunger, and at riſing up, they are either drunke, or have ſuch mind a dice, they never remember, my Lord then.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.p: No more Lord, ſirrah.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Indeed there are too many already, but is not this ſtrange, that rich men ſhould forſake their titles? maſter then.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.p: Your will ſir.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: You have left many Countries behind you in ſeeking your friend Liſander, and yet you cannot find him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: True ſir.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I haue ſeene much gold lying upon Lombards ſtals, and could never finger penny of it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Nay, twas not well ſir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: What conclude you then?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: That you were beſt ſit downe, and ſee what you haue got by your journey.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I haue ſeene a face as beautifull as heaven.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Thats nothing, a priſoner ſees the face of heaven it ſelfe, when hee lookes but out at the priſon-gate, ile ſtand to't, a man were as good be hang'd, ſo a meet a handſome hangman, & a ſtrong rope, as be in loue.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Your reaſon for that.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Mary this ſir, hanging is end of all troubles, and loue the beginning: Nay further, I thinke a Lover cannot be ſaved, for hee is of all religions.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Your proofe for that.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: This; hee thinkes with the Atheiſt there's no God but his Miſtreſſe, with the Infidell no heaven but her ſmiles, with the Papiſt no Purgatory but her frownes, and with the familie of loue, holds it lawful to lie with her, though ſhe be another mans wife.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: So ſir, what followes?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Serving-men ſir, the Maſter goes in before his wife, and the Servingman followes his maſter.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Sirra forbeare, I muſt meditate.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: As the Vſurer before hee parts with money, meditates upon the aſſurance.

div.stage: Enter Liſander privately, and over-heares them.

lg.l: If Violettaes preſence ha'not quencht
The memory of all things but her ſelfe,
I ſhould be more familiar with that face.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I haue left my countrey to ſeeke my friend.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: And I my countrey and my friend for loue.

lg.l: And in the ſearch of him haue loſt my ſelfe
In the ſtrange Region of a womans eye.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: In loue, and in Arcadia.

lg.l: As much as heaven tranſcends the humble earth,
So towres her praiſe her face differs as farre
From others, as a glo-worme from a ſtarre.
She is a Princeſſe that my ſoule affects.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: And rich.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Halfe heire unto this Dukedome.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
And ſhe were whole heire to the foure morall vertues,
twere nothing: when ſhall I ſee the time that men will loue for vertue, or a rich heire marry a poore wench without a portion? never I thinke.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Had not my friend Liſander.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: What of mee?

sp.speaker: Den • .
sp.p: Left me in Thrace.

lg.l: We had never met in loue,
His ſillables betray him. I arreſt you.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: At whoſe ſute?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Not at his Taylers in any caſe, for there's no greater ſtitch to a younger brothers conſcience, then to pay for a ſute of apparrell when tis worne out.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Liſander or his ghoſt?

lg.l: Or ſome illuſiue tenant in his ſhape?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Vnkind, why didſt thou leane my company?

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: For that which made the amorous Gods leaue heaven, • or loue: but why is Demetrius thus diſguiſ'd?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: For that which would make a Iackanapes a Monkey, and he could get it: a tayle.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.p: Peace rogue.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Why wagge, is thy maſter in loue?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Faith ſit he hath entred his action in Cutids Court, and mean • to proceed in the ſute it ſhould ſeeme.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.p: Why didſt not take my counſell in thy choice?

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Becauſe I fear'd a chiding, for doubting their honourable thoughts would not haue not haue conſented to my effeminate attempts, I ſtole this ſecret courſe, and manner of diſguiſe, as beſt helping to acceſſe, which it hath begot, now what acceſſe will bring forth, I commit to unborne induſtry.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.p: It cannot but be proſperous: only the ſtrict obſervance of our loues hinders the paſſage of our hopes.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Indeed that's not the leaſt hinderance, yet the Duke himſelfe, and my quaint diſguiſe hath removed it out of my way, who not only takes me for a woman, but hath allowed me for my loues companion.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Fortune deales kindly with thee, I am as farre from acceſſe to my loue, as when I was in Thrace.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Dametas is the oyſterſhell that holds thy pearle, our wits muſt fiſh for him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Will the Cods head bite?

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p:
Like an old Vſurer at a young heires inheritance, and I
haue it ready hookt for him: and here he comes, my plot is to preferre thee to his ſervice.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Prethee doe, and ile ſerue him in his right kind.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Dametas, my loue is yours.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Which madam I am as proud of—

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: As a malecontent of a change, or an old Lady of a new faſhion.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: To be round, I haue a ſute to you in the behalfe of this woodman

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: To me ſweet bloſſome, though I be ſomewhat ſtrict in mine office, I cannot be ſtony to Ladies. Fellow is thy petition drawne?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Petition?

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: Your onely way to moue a fute by: Humbly complayning to your good worſhip, O tis moſt patheticke, & indeed, without money, can doe juſt nothing with authority.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Come hether ſtripling, whoſe ſonne wert thou?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I am not ſo wiſe a child as you take me for, I never knew my father.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Didſt not know thy father?

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: A common fault, his betters forget themſelues when they grow rich, then blame not him to forget his father.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What was his name?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: If I may giue credite to my mother, they cald him Menalchas, who on his death-bed made me his heire, with this charge, to ſeeke your worſhips ſervice, and gaue me this gold as a remembrance to purchaſe your favour.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Gold? hem.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Now doth my Maſter long more to ſinger thar gold, then a young girle, married to an old man, doth to run her husband aſhore at Cuckolds haven.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Well, I could doe for this fatherleſſe youth.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: As many Executors and Overſeers haue done, cheate him of his portion, and then turne him out of doores a begging.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: But for I haue the Gardian-ſhip of the Princeſſe, I dare doe nothing without the conſent of the Duke.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Come, come ſir, your worſhip ſhall not refuſe him.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Well then I woo not, but tis for your ſake I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Meaning the gold.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What ſhall I call thy name?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Dorus an't like your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Ah, good Dorus, be an honeſt youth Dorus, reverence your Maſter, and loue your ſelfe: bee ſure to get under me, and you ſhall looſe nothing in my ſervice. Madam, the Duke and Dutcheſſe expect you at the hunt, and await your comming at Dianaes oake.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: • e attend them preſently, be a good ſervant Dorus.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Twill be his owne another day Madam.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: In the meane time let it be yours to lead the way.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: My ſervice doth attend you.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: As the Purſevant doth the priſoner for a double fee.

lg.l: Welcome ſlaue to a ſlaue, a faire preſage,
The hope of loue ſweetens loues vaſſ lage.

div.stage: Enter Aminter and Iulio, attired like Satires.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Now and Dametas bee the mettle hee was ſtampt for, a right villaine.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: And he be not, hang him.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Nay he deſerues hanging too if he be: but will you truſt him?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Yes as farre as I ſee him, and he that truſts him further, my truſt is he will be deceived.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Indeed, he that will proue falſe to his maker, will be true to no man.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Yes, for the preſent time, like a bawd to him that giues moſt

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Thats not for loue.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Yes of the money: he that lookes for other loue in this age—This is the place his Letter ſpeakes of, and here he comes himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Why ſo lo: now is the web of my hopes upon the Loombe of perfection, and in this quech of laſhes Aminter & Iulio,

lg.l: See and ſee not, all mum, you know your cue,
The game's your owne, if you can hunt it true.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Dametas, were thine cares ever at a more muſicall banquet? how the hounds mouths like bels are tuned one under another like a ſlothfulneſſe, the ſpeed of the cry out-ran my ſenſe of hearing.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Croſſe over the Forreſt to Dianaes oake my liege, & there your grace advantag'd by the height of the ground, ſhall not onely at pleaſure heare, but be eye-witneſſe of their muſicall contention.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Thankes good Dametas, bee thy directions our wiues convoy.

sp.speaker: Gyn.
sp.p: Where is his highneſſe Dametas?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: At Adonis bower Madam, where he expects your preſence, to ſee the fleſhing of a couple of Spartane hounds, in the waſting blood of the ſpent Deare.

sp.speaker: Gyn.
sp.p: Thankes good Dametas, mine eyes would not be good friends with my feet, ſhould they not bring 'em to that kingly ſport.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Sweet Ladies, to ſaue you the expence of much breath, which muſt be laid out in the purchaſe of the game, I haue provided you this ſtand, from whence your eyes may be commanders of the ſport: ſuch ſport as you little dreame of.

lg.l: We are your loues debters kind Dametas.
As I loue vertue I pitty theſe poore beaſts,
Theſe Syl • ane commoners, to ſee what taskes
Our covetous Forreſters impoſe upon them,
Who not content with impoſt of their breath,
(Poore hearts) purſue them ſmiling to their death.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Twas the end of their creation Madam.

lg.l: So was the end of ours to liue in peace,
And not to tyranniſe on harmeleſſe beaſts,
But Forreſters, like Images ſet forth
The tyrannie of greatneſſe without pitty,
As they the Deare, ſo covetous wealth purſues
The trembling ſtate of their inferiors,
And to claſpe up the volume of their ſinnes,
They drinke their blood, and cloath them with their skins:
Then ceaſe to preſſe poore beaſts with tyrannie,
You loue your liues, thinke they are loath to dye.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: You are too tender-hearted to bee a good huntſwoman Lady.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: And ſome of you too hard-hearted, but leaving this diſcourſe of hunting, haue all our gallantry of Lacedemon and Greece, ſpent the vigor of their wits, that not one dares venter.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: For our loues ſiſter, you may ſee, the properer women, the worſe lucke.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Tuſh you ſhall haue ſuters, feare not Madam.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: No at any hand ſiſter, for with a feare it comes.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Then ile feare of purpoſe, becauſe I would haue 'em come.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: And they doe not, they are notable cowards.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
Then let them keepe away ſtill, for I haue vowed my maidenhead
ſhall never doe homage to the bed of a coward.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Sweet Ladies, will you beguile a minute or two with this diſcourſe, till I ſtep up to the top of the hill▪ and make diſcovery of the game.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Let your returne be ſpeedy good Dametas.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Ile put on wings and fly.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Out of the Court, and the whole Countrey ſhall haue a good riddance.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: So, he hath put'em faire to the ſtand, lets iſſue & ſurpriſe them.

lg.l: Be reſolute and ſuddaine.
Aminter and Iulio iſſue out, and beare them away.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Murther, treaſon, reſcue, helpe.

div.stage: Enter firſt Dametas, and then the Duke.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Yes much reskue, much helpe, much Dametas: why ſo, this jeſt was drawen home cloſe to the head, it cannot chuſe but cleaue the very white of our hopes, the Dukes wit: to thy tackle good wit, ſome ſudden ſea roome, or our ſtratagem is run a ground.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Tell me Dametas, was not the Deare a prodigall? did hee not ſpend his breath freely amongſt us?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: And his blood too my liege, but did you obſerue how the hounds like politicians nos'd out the game?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: True: and comming to the loſſe, Melampus, but where are our daughters?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Did you obſerue that my liege, that Melampus as a true hound is ever horce cheerd or hollow, yet he kept time too.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Certaine Dametas, but where are our daughters man?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Buſie my Lord under a brake buſh, diſputing of the vertue of ſweet water, and ground Iuie.

div.stage: Cry within, treaſon, murder, reskue, helpe.

lg.l: What cry of treaſon's that Dametas?
Pray God no danger ſets upon my daughters,
Seeke out our wife, ile haſte unto their reskue.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: And my ſword un-employd? alleageance ſayes nay to that my • i • ge, I am for the adventure my ſelfe, if they be ſurpris'd (I am a mad man) your grace ſhall heare more: if not (I am the more ſorry) your grace ſhall heare more too: make peace with your thoughts till my returne, and doubt not their recovery.

div.stage: Enter the Dutcheſſe with her daughters, Demetrius, Liſander, &c.

sp.speaker: Gyn.
sp.p: Speake, where's the Duke?

sp.speaker: Baſi.
sp.p:
Here my Gynetia.
What meane theſe weapons, are our daughters • afe?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: As a thiefe in a mill father, we thanke our redeemers▪

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: The more my griefe, were you ſurpriſ'd then madam?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Yes faith Dametas.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: And how ſweet Ladies, and how were you reſcued?

lg.l: Being ſurpriſ'd, this gallant Amazon
Preſt to their re • cue, had you ſeene what worth
She and this woodman ſpent in our defence,
Wonder would ha' bereft you of all ſenſe,
She rai▪'d her ſword with ſuch a manly grace,
As had not her mild ſexe contrould my thoughts,
I could haue falne in loue with her high worth.
You over-priſe us madam, not our deſert,
But the weake ſpirits of our oppoſites,
Gaue luſter to the dimneſſe of our worth.
It pleaſeth your modeſty to leſſon it,
But it ſhall ſtill liue great in our regard. What woodman's that?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: My follower, my liege.

lg.l: What ere he be, he hath deſeru'd our loue,
Fellow be neere us, and for this deſert,
Perform'd againſt thoſe Traytors to our blood,
Vnder thy maſter we giue thee an attendant,
To guard the life and ſafetie of our daughter.
Thanke you good father, who ever looſe by the bargaine,
I haue got me a ſervant by the match: woo't ſerue me fellow?
In the beſt I can.
In heart your fellow, though in ſhow your man.
Ile try your dutious ſervice: I command
Your knee to ki •• e the ground, your lip my hand.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Pardon me Madam.

lg.l: Here's hot loue no doubt,
I may command my man, and goe without.
Truce to this ayrie warre, theſe paper bullets
Better become a Cloſſet then a Parke,
The Forreſt muſicke is to heare the hounds
Rend the thin ayre, and with a luſty cry
Awake the drowſie Eccho, and confound
Their perfect language in a mingled ſound,
Then to the Court, our Forreſt ſport being done,
A ſecond chace of lovelier ſports begunne.
If fortune croſſe not what our hopes purſue,
Our feares have met their deaths, our loves their due.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Croſt in my hopes, the Ladies reſcu'd, and the Princes like • ravens beat out of the game-place, my invention muſt turne traveller for more ſtratagems: what & I ſhould diſcover their plot to the Duke, attach em for traitors, and beg their lands for my labour, though they be my friends, twere a pretty parcell of pollicy.

lg.l: All things are lawfull that doe profit bring,
A wiſe mans bow goes with a two-fold ſtring.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Did ever two Princes meet ſuch ſtrange changes in their loves? now we have wrought our admittance, and in a manner got em into our poſſeſſions, our hopes like falſe fires having brought us within ken, vaniſh, and leave us out of all comfort.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: That the Duke ſhould doat upon thee for a woman, makes for our purpoſe, but that the Dutcheſſe ſhould be enamourd on thee for a man, is prepoſterous.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Whether my valour ſhown in the reskue of the Ladies, or the ardent glances her daughters beauty ſteales from my eyes, give her thoughts encouragement, I know not, but her hopes ſtand confident I am a man, and for that cauſe am I barr'd from acceſſe.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: I weigh thy combrances by my own, for though by the dukes allowance I am her priviledg'd attendant, yet ſuch is the deviliſhnes of Dametas, that I cannot joy ſo much acceſſe as to confer with her.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: I can compare my lord & his friend to nothing in the world ſo fitly, as to a couple of water buckets, for whil'ſt hope winds the one up, diſpaire plunges the other down, whil'ſt I, like a Harlakene in an Italian Comoedy, ſtand making faces at both their follies.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Well, ſince the ſhape of our proceeding growes ſo monſtrous, lets caſt our inventions in a new mold, and having ſo firme a foundation as this diſguiſe to build upon, lets draw the modell, and raiſe the whole frame of our attempts anew.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.p: Indeed, lovers ſhould be condition'd like tyrants, who having the aime of a crowne in their eye once, runne violently over all lets that intervent their courſe, and ſo muſt we.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p:
And ſo will we, my reſolution is already bent, and if I ſhoot not, the next levell I take, Love I beſeech thee breake thy bow about mine eares, and ſtrike thy hornes in my forhead, for married
men to hang their cap • on.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I have met a meanes fit for my purpoſe already: Mopſa Dametas onely daughter is overſhooes in love with me, & to her • le feigne extreame ardor of affection, and make her the ſhadow under which Ile court the true ſubſtance of my divine Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: About it then, Ile ſweat my invention to death but Ile overtake thee; but heere comes one of my Burres▪ I muſt beare his importunity, for no reaſonable denyall will bruſh him off.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Zelmane.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: My Liege.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: My thoughts come like a ſaile afore the wind, ſwolne big with news, and thine eares the midwife muſt deliver me of this burden: my Dutcheſſe is ſicke, heart-ſicke for thee Zelmane.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: For me? why my Lord, I am no Roſa ſolis, nor Aqua mirabilis to recover ſicke folkes.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Shall I be ſhort with thee? My Ladie's in love with thee.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: With me my Lord?

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: With thee my Lady: her amorous glances are her accuſers, her very looks write Sonnets in thy commendations, ſhe carves thee at boord, and cannot ſleepe for dreaming on thee in bed, ſhee's turn'd ſunne-riſer, haunts private walkes, and like a diſgrac'd Courtier, ſtudies the Art of melancholly.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Now alas good Lady.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Nay never pitty her, ſhe deſerves none, rather lets bend our indeavors to intangle her more. To ſee the kindnes of fortune, who fearing we ſhould be acquainted with ſollitude in this our 12 month retirement, hath begot a domeſticall merriment, and made our own thoughts Actors in't, and as bad a Poet as I am, Ile ha one ſcene in't of my owne invention.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Dametas will ſtorme at that, for hee cannot abide Poetry ſhould be countenanc'd; but how is't my Liege?

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Tis ready plotted already, and that the Dutcheſſe may not find thee unprovided when ſhe comes to court thee.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Court me, court a woman my Liege?

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Why that's the very happineſſe of the jeſt, but in any caſe confeſſe thy ſelfe a man.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: A man my Liege? I ha no colour for't.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Tuſh, Ile furniſh thee, ſay thou art a Prince, no matter who, and haſt to doe with this diſguiſe of purpoſe to court my daughter Violetta.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Is this ſcene of your owne inventing my Liege?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Mine own ifaith, and to confirm't the rather, uſe more oft and private conference with my daughter, interchange diſcourſe & amorous dalliance, oh twill ſet my Dutcheſſe affections afire, to think her rivalld by her daughter, and give us ſmooth paſſage to our love.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: How occaſion playes the wanton with me. Well my liege, do but you work my admittance to your daughter, and • le beſtow al the art I am worth in courting her; and ſee, as if Fortune had a hand in our Comoedy, ſhe hath entred the Dutcheſſe juſt at her cue, ſhaddow your ſelfe in your Arke, and leave me to give her entertainment.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Forget not to perſonate ſome Prince in any caſe.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: I warrant you, Ile play the Prince with much art.

lg.l: This way he went, on this ſweet violet bed
Still dwells the print of his inamour'd tread,
The depreſt flowers have ſtrengthened their ſweet
By ſtealing amorous kiſſes from his feet.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Abſolute Poet. Penelope was a ballad-maker to her.

lg.l: Oh doe not fly my preſence, gentle wanton ſtay,
What haue I found you, faith you run-away
Ile tye a chaine about your waſt for this,
And make you buy your freedome with a kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Fie Madam, this courteſy is more then needes.

lg.l: Be not ſo coy, let not a loving Dame
Find thee leſſe kind then ſenſeleſſe elements,
Thou never walk'ſt, but the enamour'd aire
Like an officious lover beares thy traine,
Whil'ſt the coole wind doth with his velvet wing
Fanne the thinne ayre upon thy ſweaty cheeke,
Stealing ſweet kiſſes from thy ſilken lip.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Shield this vain breath, beat at ſome Ladies eare.

lg.l: But you are none, you are not, come you are not.
Your valour, lookes, and geſture ſhow you are not,
Your manly brow, and your commanding eye,
Where warre and fortune dwell in majeſtie,
Your private walkes, and varied paſſions,
Your glances to my daughter, ſure you are not,
And my firme love is confident you are not.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: There's a lover of a right temper, ſhee'l out-face the name of her ſexe inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Well Madam, ſith your obſervation hath diſcover'd me, upon promiſe of your ſecrecy, I confeſſe my ſelfe a man.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Good, excellent, how truely ſhe takes my directions.

lg.l: I knew my judgement could not be deceiv'd,
Nor durſt proud love have done me ſo much wrong
To caſt my thoughts unto a womans eye.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Love durſt not, good, good, excellent, what next?

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: But Madam, now I am known to you, what further requeſt you?

lg.l: Exchange of lookes, and freedome of thy bed,
Thy preſence, thy embracements, thy kind love,
For which my amorous thoughts have long lyen ſicke.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Thank you good wife; nay, and a Dutcheſſe long to give her husband the horning, let it never grieve Butchers to doe homage at Cuckolds haven.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Well Madam, to give content to your affections, and in a ſtrong hope you will mediate my ſute to your daughter, ſort out but fit time and opportunity, and maſter your deſires.

sp.speaker: Baſil▪
sp.p: And he were a man now I might be rarely tupt.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Give me thy hand then, with this amorous kiſſe I ſeale thee mine.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: And I confirm't with this.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Rare, rare, rare, ſhee's his, ſeald and deliverd in the preſence of her husband.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Now leſt my husband ſhould ſuſpect our love.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Now, what for that now?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Heare a good jeſt, perſwade him thou art a woman.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: That's not to doe now Madam, for he as confidently beleeves and ardently courts me for a woman as you for a man.

lg.l: Good, excellent, maintaine that humour ſtill,
Seeme coy, looke nice, and as we women uſe,
Be mild, and proud, imbrace, and yet refuſe.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Excellent vertues in a woman.

lg.l: I prithee doe, twill be a ſcene of mirth
For me to quote his paſſions and his ſmiles,
His amorous haviour, and how his eye
Will beget ſtrange variety of lookes,
And ſhoot em into thine; but the chiefe ſport's this,
To ſee an old man with a young man kiſſe.
To ſee an old Dutcheſſe a young Lady kiſſe.
Now the plot packs, the ſcene's all comicall,
I cannot ſpeake for laughter, to ſee theſe women,
That would be counted wonders for their wit,
Lay plots to gull themſelves, ſilly conceit.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: To take me for a man.

lg.l: And arme her ſelfe
To laugh at me, make jeſts and ſcoffes at me,
But ſooth her humour, the revenge ſhee'd throw
Vpon my head, ſhall fall on her owne brow.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Vpon you both, ſo, ſo, ſo, how greedily their inventions like bugles follow the ſent of their owne gullery, yet theſe are no fooles, God forbid, not they: but to the drift, mirth in my warme blood ſits Laughing at this diviſion of their wits.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Woo't beleeve mee ſiſter? I never eat a cherry, but it puts mee in mind of a husband, it kiſſes my lips with ſuch a harmeleſſe prettineſſe.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Now in good deed lo I loue em a liſe too, I thinke I ſhall never ha my belly full on em.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Of what, not of husbands Violetta?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: No, of cherries Hippolita, but take heed of em, they bee a very filling meat, and dangerous things for us Maydes I can tell you, we may ſurfet after em preſently.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Surfet after what, a husband?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: I, and after cherries too Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I warrant you ſiſter, an old Lady in Lacedemon taught me a preſervative againſt that.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: For the love of cherries what?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Marry this it was, ſtill ſaid ſhe, betwixt every cherry ſaid ſhe, be ſure to cracke a ſtone ſaid ſhe.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Then let me alone, Ile cracke a couple of ſtones betwixt every cherry, rather then ſurfet on them.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You muſt take heed you cracke not too many too, for you may ſurfet of the ſtone as well as of the cherry.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Nay and they be ſuch dangerous things, I ha done with em.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: So have I too for this time, but ſiſter, is it not a ſtrange kind of ſervile liberty that we live in here in Arcadia?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: For all the world as Engliſhmen keep their fellons, and Italians their wives, we never ſtirre abroad without our laylors.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And for what cauſe forſooth? only to keep us from mariage.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p:
Sure it is either ſome high content, or extreame diſcommoditie,
that our father debarres us of it.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: By this ſtone, me thinks I long like a woman with child, till I know the difference betwixt a Mayd and a wife.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Well, god a mercy of all curſen ſoules, I was neere the knowledge on't laſt night I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O that I had bin with thee I might ha been ſo too: for the love of marriage how?

lg.l: Why thus: As I lay ſlumbring in my bed,
No creature with me but my mayden-head.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Is that a creature?

lg.l: Some maintaine it is,
Got in the eye, conceived in a kiſſe;
Others, whoſe ſpeech ſeemes neere akin to truth,
Say tis a paſſion, bred i'th heat of youth,
Some call't a ſigh, and ſome an amorous grone,
All differ in the definition:
But in th'allow'd opinion of moſt,
Tis never truely had till it be loſt.
But lying thus alone, as Mayds doe uſe,
Me thought I dreamt, as Mayds can hardly chuſe,
And in my dreame me thought twas too much wrong
A pretty Mayd ſhould lye alone ſo long;
With that a gallant comes, gallants can doe
Much with young Mayds.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And with old women too.

lg.l: He courted me once, and agen, and thrice,
Tis vertue to ſay nay, to bee too nice
Agrees not with my humour, yet ſome ſay,
We Mayds wiſh things, to which we anſwer nay;
Briefely, me thought he ſtood ſo long a wooing,
I rather could ha wiſht he had been doing
Some other buſineſſe, yet at laſt we'greed,
Twere ſtrange if earneſt futers ſhould not ſpeed.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: In what agreed you?

lg.l: In our Wedding-ring,
Time, place, and houre, indeed in every thing;
The day appoynted, and each thing in frame,
I thought each houre an age untill it came,
Well, come it is, the morning once in ſight,
I thought it ten times longer till twas night.
At dinner time me thought I ſweld with pride
To be drunke to by name of Miſtreſſe bride,
Muſicke ſpake loud, no delicates were ſcant,
Yet ſtill me thought another thing did want,
For ſure thought I, there's ſomething in a man
That wiues loue well, hope brides may wiſh it than.
Long lookt for comes at laſt, to bed we goe.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Would I had dreamt I might ha' done ſo too.

lg.l: My bed-mate turn'd, and as he would ha' ſpoke,
I ſweat with feare, and in that feare I woke,
But ſeeing my kind bed-fellow was gone,
Lord how it chaft me that I wakt ſo ſoone,
One minuts dreaming longer, I had tride,
The difference twixt a virgin and a bride.
Otwould ha' vext a Saint, my blood would burne
To be ſo neere, and miſſe ſo good a turne.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And ſo did mine too I warrant you, nay though I bee but a little pot, I ſhall be as ſoone hot as another.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You ſhould not be my ſiſter elſe.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Nor my mothers daughter neither.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
And in good earneſt wee are not fath • r •
〈…〉 amiſſe.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Are you avis'd of that, and Ifaith tell •… what thinke you of your ſervant Dorus.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: As of a ſweet Almond in a rugged ſhell, the Sun in a cloud, or a wealthy Diamond in a rocke, indeed cleane contrary to the world, hee weares the worſt ſide outward, and is much better then he ſeemes: but what thinke you of your manly Amazon??

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Nay the ſport is I know not what to thinke, Zelmanes humour would afford project for a pretty Court Comoedy, my father courts her for a woman, and as I feare ſhe is, my mother doats upon her for a man, and as I wiſh he were, and that with ſuch an ardor of affection, that I could find in my heart to turne my mother out of the company, and play the lovers part my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: How ever man or woman, the jeſt holds currant in one.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I know not what knaviſh motion hath had to doe with my thought, but my mind tels mee that your ſervant Dorus and my Amazon, are other then they ſeeme: and here he comes.
sp.stage: Enter firſt Liſander, then Miſo, Mopſa, Demetrius.

sp.speaker: Miſo.
sp.p: Why how now madam, Ladies gadding, is this the obedience of your fathers charge.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Pardon Miſtreſſe Miſo, 'twas my doing and the Dukes.

sp.speaker: Miſo.
sp.p: But the Dutcheſſe will like neither the Dukes doings nor yours, neither in this caſe I can tell you. The Duke ſtaies your comming, and yet the Dutcheſſe is very deſirous on't, my husband is in the next Arbour to man you. For you Lady, my preſence be your priviledge.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Miſo ſhould be either a hang man or a Herald, for ſhe never comes amongſt us, but ſhe quarters our company and armes.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Excellent beauty, & therefore more excellent, becauſe ſituate in ſo faire a creature.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: You are a merry man Dorus, but all this cannot make me loue me, how ſay you mother doth he?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Mary let him chuſe daughter, when I was as thou art—

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You were as ſhe is? but faith madam Mopſa, I perceiue my ſervant Dorus beares a moneths mind to you, bee not ſo ſtraight laced to him.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Straight lac'd? ſgod mend me I am not lac'd at all, am I Dorus? no in ſooth, I goe wide ope wenſday, I never lace my ſelfe but on ſundayes, & that for feare I ſhould burſt with cating of plum-porridge.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I meane let fall ſome comfortable lookes on your ſuter.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Sgod mend me, ile let fall or take up any thing I haue to doe him good.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Why that's kindly ſaid, and Dorus your loue is very ambitious, to climbe ſo high as the beautifull Mopſa.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: O are you avis'd of that, 'twould make a horſe breake his bridle to heare how the youth of the village will commend me, oh the pretty little pincking nies of Mopſa ſayes one, oh the fine flat lips of Mopſa ſayes another, and then doe I bridle my head like a malt-horſe thus, ſet mine armes a kembo thus, wreath my necke and my body thus, winke with one eye thus, and ſpread my peacocks tay le as broad as the proudeſt minxe of em all.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Theſe extraordinary graces muſt not want admiration, but where's your mother?

sp.speaker: Miſo.
sp.p: Speake ſoftly in the Lobby there, for waking my Ladies foiſting hound.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Godſme, my mother's ſtealing of a nap.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Nay, ſhee cannot bee ſaid to ſteale a nap, for the noiſe ſhee makes herſelfe would diſcover her theft: but Dorus ſith your fortunes are poore, you ſhould ſtudy to enoble your deſerts, and beget effects worthy to court and win your Ladies acceptance.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p:
Laſſe madam, I chuſe no better moderater then your ſelfe,
betwixt me & my unworthy ſervices, ſuppoſe your ſelfe though but a Cucko compar'd with this ſweet ſinging Nitingale, ſhould be ſued to by a Prince like me, I meane like me in loue, for loue in Princes & peſants admits compariſon: ſuppoſe Demetrius ſhould in like diſguiſe court you as I doe, Mopſa, ſigh for you, as I doe, for Mopſa, kneele to you thus, as I doe, to Mopſa, lay downe his life to you, as I doe, to Mopſa, prefer your good before his owne, as I proteſt I do, Mopſaes, ſuppoſe he ſhould ſhew you the knowen marke of his neck, to aſſure you he were Demetrius, as I doe this to Mopſa, to witneſſe I am the ſonne of Menalchas, could your disdaine ſtand out like Mopſaes?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: What a keenes neceſſitie ſets upon the edge of invention, truſt me Mopſa your ſervant ſpeakes well, and if hee can proue himſelfe the man he ſpeakes of, and my wiſhes well hope, Demetrius, you haue no reaſon to thinke ſcorne of him.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Why what ſhould I doe Madam? my mother tels me I muſt not ſay as I thinke.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I am no counſeller, but ſhould Demetrius in like diſguiſe court me, thus would I embrace him, thus ſeale my affections with a kiſſe, and thus argue: thinke not Demetrius that the clouds of baſeneſſe could ſo muſfle thee, but that the Sun of valour ſhind through them long ſince, and in regard of thy ſerviceable dutie in concealing, and unprevented policy in thus making knowen thy loue, ſort but out fit opportunity, and in deſpight of al guardians ſtrict obſervance, goe where thou wilt, the worth of Demetrius ſhall draw Hippolita, this would I vow, and this will I performe.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: And were I Demetrius and you Hippolita, I would deceiue Dametas, outreach Miſo, forſweare Mopſa, and forſake Arcadia, to ſhare the fortunes of divine Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: And what ſhould I doe then?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I doe but ſpeake in the perſon of Demetrius, and under Hippolita ſhadow what I intend to the rare, and never enough wondred at Mopſa, the blacke ſwan of beauty, and madg-howlet of admiration.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Doe not you flout me Dorus? and you doe not, provide a Prieſt and ile marry you, and my father and mother ſhall never know on't.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Manaſſes is the man.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: And ile bee the woman, whoſoever ſay nay to't, little dreames my mother of what we haue done.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: T'may be ſhe did, for ſhe ſigh'd & groand much in her ſleepe.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p:
Tis well ſhee was ſo quiet, for ſhee eate peaſe-poridge to breakefaſt, and they'l make mebreake wind in my ſleepe like a horſe,
and ſee as the devill will ha't ſhe wakes, and here comes my father, no words and yee loue me.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Why God a mercy Dorus, this diligence becomes the ſervant of Dametas, and ile preferre thee for't.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You were worſe then the devill elſe, for they ſay hee helps his ſervants, then you may doe little and you cannot helpe yours.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Will you breake your jeſts againſt the bars of your chamber window, and cleare the greene? the Duke is comming to bowles, and I would not for halfe mine office you ſhould be a rub in the way of his patience: daughter and wife, conduct her to the Lodge, Exit. And Dorus, make you haſte about your buſines.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I warrant you Sir: be my hopes rightly plac't, You will condemne me for my too much haſte.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Why ſo: this tis to be in authority: Inferiour perſons, I and the Princes themſelues, fly from my preſence, like the chirping Birds from the ſight of the Faulcon: my very breath like a mighty wind blowes away inferiour Officers (the Court rubbiſh) out of my way, and giues me a ſmooth paſſage: I am the morning ſtarre, I am ſeldome ſeene but about the riſing of the Sunne: indeed I am never out of the Dukes eye; and here he comes.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Doth our match hold?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Yes, whoſe part will you take?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Zelmanes.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Soft, that match is yet to make.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Lets caſt a choiſe, the neereſt two take one.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: My choice is caſt, helpe ſweet occaſion.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Come, here's agood.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Well, better'd.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Beſt of all.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: The Duke and I.

sp.speaker: Duk
sp.p: The weakeſt goe to the wall.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Ile leade.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Ile follow.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: We haue both one mind.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: In what?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: In leaving the old folke behind.

lg.l: Well jeſted daughter, and you leade not faire,
The hindmoſt hound, though old, may catch the hare.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Your laſt bowle, come.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: By the faith a me, well lead.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Would I might leade you.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: To my bed.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: I am ſure you would not.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: By this aire I would.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: I hope you would not hurt me, and you ſhould.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: I'de love you ſweet.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Soure, ſo I heard you ſay.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: A cept it then.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Of what acquaintance pray?

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Of loves and mine.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Daughter, your bowle winnes one.

lg.l: None of my Maydenhead father, I am gone,
The Amazon hath wonne one.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Yield to that.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: The caſt I doe.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Your ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Nay ſcrape out that.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Whoſe is it yet?

lg.l: The Dukes: play ſmooth and fine.
The ſmalleſt helpe that is will make you mine.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Me yours?

lg.l: You mine, for though the caſt I loſe,
I ha wonne your love.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Much: in my tother hoſe.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Come, the laſt marke; this caſt is worth all the reſt,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: The leader as the follower.

lg.l: Bad's the beſt.
I winne her for ten Crownes, and there they be.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: I take your lay.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: A match twixt you and me.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Ile be your halfe.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: That were unkindly done.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Pardon me mother, Ile beare all or none.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: I ha wonne you Madam.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Me?

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: I meane your bet.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Then take your winnings, Ile not die in debt.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Madam beleeve mee, I am, as I proteſt, a Prince, my name Liſander.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Looke to the Dukes ſtanding Madam.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: So I will I warrant you, and to your falling.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Thus clouded as you ſee for your love, my ſoule ſpeakes in my tongue; I appoynted this match at Bowles a purpoſe to acquaint you with it.

lg.l: Barre ſtealing Father; yet and all hit right,
Here's one would ſteale a piece of fleſh to night.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Deere Madam.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: No more words, I have perceived as much in your eye, as you can expreſſe with your tongue, and as farre as my mothers jealouſy would give me leave, anſwered it with kind lookes: your bias ſtands wrong mother.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Why? it ſtands toward Zelmanes.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Hath it ſtood ſo long?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: All the game through.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Then all your game's bowld wrong: furniſh you with neceſſaries befitting an eſcape, and my will ſhall be as ready to take wing as yours: put in a caſt now mother, or the game is gone indeed.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Whoſe is the throw?

lg.l: Ours, till the laſt bowle came;
But that hath wonn't em cleere, both caſt and game.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Our winnings, come, a kiſſe and bate the reſt.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: What, doe you kiſſe in eaneſt or in jeſt?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: In earneſt in good truth.

lg.l: Troth kindly ſed,
Take heed you kiſſe not out your Mayden-head.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: In jeſt?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: In earneſt.

lg.l: Tis the faſhion,
Much in requeſt among our nation.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: To kiſſe away their Maiden-heads?

lg.l: Now and then,
And being gone, to kiſſe it backe agen:
For lovers indentures nere are fairly drawn,
Vntill the Maiden-head be left in pawne,
As earneſt of the match, ſo mothers ſed,
And ſo will daughters doe when mams be dead.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: What pawne their Maydenheads?

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Yes, and loſe em too.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: And you' • maintaine that faſhion?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Signeor Noe.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Lay by this home-bred mirth, and prepare your eares to entertaine ſtrangers.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Strangers? why father ſtrangers are as welcome to mee, as mine owne Country-men, if they bring good manners and civill humanity in their company; otherwiſe, they are like foule weather, come afore they be ſent for.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Dametas? nay then we ſhall have newes enough, for he never comes into the preſence, but he brings a whole ſacke full of lies, of newes I ſhould ſay.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Welcome Dametas: what officious fellow is that?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: A pure well willer of your Majeſties, and a follower of mine.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: O tis Manaſſes, and he could make armes as well as he ma • res legs, hee would grow in great requeſt for Heraldry: What's your newes?

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: Theſe Lacedemonians, ſubjects to your Majeſty, having a meſſage to deliver to your Majeſties inſtruments of hearing, commonly eclip'd eares.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: How, hath any one here clipt eares?

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: Sweete Feminine, clip off the taile of thy diſcourſe with the Siſſars of attention, as I ſay, theſe Lacedemonians have choſen me their tongue.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Of a long tongue thou ſpeakeſt very little.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: That proves me no woman, for they ſpeake over much.

sp.speaker: Duk
sp.p: What grievances oppreſſe them? briefely ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Merchandize (my Liege) through the avarice of purchaſing Officers, is wrackt with ſuch unmercifull impoſt, that the very name of Trafficke growes odious even to the profeſſour.

sp.speaker: Iulio
sp.p: Townes ſo oppreſt for want of wonted and naturall liberty, as that the native Inhabitanus feeme Slaves, and the Forreiners free Denizens.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Offices ſo bought and ſold, that before the purchaſer can be ſayd to be placed in his office, he is againe by his covetous Patron diſplac'd.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Common Riots, Rapes, and wilfull Homicide in great mens followers, not onely not puniſhed, but in a manner countenanced and applauded.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Indeed ſince your Majeſtie left the Land, the whole body of the Common-wealth runs cleane againſt the bias of true and priſtine governement.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: And your honourable Brother, like a ſhip toſt upon the violent billowes of this inſurrection, by us intreats your Majeſties Letters of ſpeedy reformation, for feare the whole Kingdome ſuffer inevitable ſhipwracke.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Which after ſhort deliberation with our Councell, your ſelfe ſhall returne. Dametas reward their travels with two hundred Crownes: in the meane time, let them taſte the beſt entertainement of our Court.

lg.l: Proud Rebels, they ſhall ſee that a Dukes frowne,
Can at his pleaſure, turne Rebellion downe:
See them rewarded.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.p: Manaſſes, ſee the fellowes entertayned; I muſt attend of the Duke.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Boy, ſee the fellowes entertayned; I muſt waite of my Lord.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Fellowes, be as merry as you may, I muſt follow my M.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: So, here's Petitioners attendance right; good words, and ſhort Commons: But tis not their entertainement wee come for. I made a ſimple ſhift to get entertainement into the Court.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.p: Well Cupid, pray for our liues, for and wee were gone, I know not where thou wouldſt haue two ſuch ſtates-men againe.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: His Common-wealth could not ſtand without us; and that his Mother knowes well enough: and hee ſends no better ſucceſſe then we had at our hunting, he looſes a friend of me.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.p: 'Twill not ſinke in my thought yet, but that old muſty ſlaue Dametas played the ſlaue with us.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Would I could proue it once: but ſince wee are againe admitted our Realme, ſhall wee be idle? ſomewhat weele doe, though they'l giue us but ſmall thankes for our labour.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.p: The Duke ſhall not ſay his Daughters are ſo ill beloved, but vveele change a thruſt or two vvith his intent for'em.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: T'vvould put the poore Wenches out of conceit vvith themſelues, and there ſhould not be ſome contending for them.
We are in the way to catch the old one, and then our ayme 〈…〉 .
We are ifaith: Invention could not weaue, 〈…〉 , Suſpition to deceiue.
