Come, paſſe off this groveling imitation; a Lovers 〈…〉 muſt bee ambitious, and like the Eagle, ſcorning the baſe 〈…〉 where Kites and Crowes lie flagging: mount the cleare sky of 〈…〉 , and overpeere all hindrances:
The Ladies themſelues are willing.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Ready to embarke upon the next tide of occaſion whatſoever.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.p: Let mee alone to worke it then▪ But here comes my Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: 'Twere more for your credite Sir, and you could ſay your man: but men and warre were worne out of faſhion both in a Summer.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: I am of thy beliefe in that Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Would my Lord were ſo too ſir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Suppoſe I were Sir, what then?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I ſhould (as many upſtarts haue done) proue rich: for I beleeue you would make me your heire.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Is that part of your beliefe?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A principall poynt ſir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Renounce it then, for I beleeue you'l never be ſaved by't.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I am ſure I cannot looſe by't. I beleeue further, that many Knights, and ſome Ladies, were never of Gods making.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Of whoſe then, wagge?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Ile tell you: the Minters coyne Gold, Gold makes Heralds, Heralds makes Knights, and Knights ſtampe Ladies.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: And what doe Ladies?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: They liue not idle neither; they make ſome Knights, and marre many Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Ladies are good worke-women too, then?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Farre better then any Taylor: they'l make you an end of a ſuite, eſpecially a Court ſuite, when all the Taylors in a Countrey know not how to ſet a ſtitch in't▪

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I am of the beliefe you are a knaue, ſir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I had no faith, ſhould I ſay you were not?

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Well, what a Knaue?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: In a Knaues beliefe ſir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Becauſe in yours?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Doe you ſay't, and ile ſweare it, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: No more Boy, I am weary of your jeſts.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: That confirmes them to be good ſir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Your reaſon for that, ſir?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Becauſe travellers and lovers, are ſoone weary of goodneſſe.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Goodly ones indeed: but leaving this high-way of circumſtance; I ſent you for Manaſſes.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The learned Scribe attends you.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Will you fall off ſir?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Like an Apple at Michaelmas, without ſhaking.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Welcome Manaſſes: I haue preſent employment for thee, in which I muſt borrow—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Pardon me Madam, I learned of my Lord, to lend nothing without ſecuritie and pawnes.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: 'Tis not money (Manaſſes) but counſell and furtherance that we deſire.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Good counſell is worth good money Madam.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt bee well conſidered; there's twenty Crownes in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay Madam, this hand is like a fellow that takes every thing in jeſt; if you be in earneſt, let me feele it here: So Lady, now betwixt earneſt and jeſt, if your Will be ready drawne, before your friend delivered as your deed, and put me in truſt to execute it.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Take it this, in a word honeſt Sheepheard, and thy Lords daughter Madam Mopſa, are man and wife.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Man, and woman perhaps, but not man and wife: for though moſt women haue a will to bee Ladies, like my Lords wife; yet every Lady hath not wit to bee a wife, as my Lords Daughter. But what good can I doe in this?

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Overy much: for though they bee man and wife by oath and proteſtation, the chiefeſt ceremony of all; namely Mariage is yet unperformed, and hearing that you haue • ane orders.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: That I haue: I haue tane order for the making away of a hundred Maidenheads in my time, and not ſo few: but I am in the mind of you now, theſe two beagles, Dorus and Mopſa, haue runne themſelues breathleſſe in the chaſe of loue, you would ha' me couple them up in the leaſes of Matrimonie.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: We are in the way to catch the old one, and then our ayme deceiues not.

lg.l: We are ifaith: Invention could not weaue,
A quainter web, Suſpition to deceiue.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.p: Come, paſſe off this groveling imitation; a Lovers thoughts muſt bee ambitious, and like the Eagle, ſcorning the baſe ayre where Kites and Crowes lie flagging: mount the cleare sky of Invention, and overpeere all hindrances:
The Ladies themſelues are willing.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Ready to embarke upon the next tide of occaſion whatſoever.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.p: Let mee alone to worke it then, But here comes my Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: 'Twere more for your credite Sir, and you could ſay your man: but men and warre were worne out of faſhion both in a Summer.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: I am of thy beliefe in that Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Would my Lord were ſo too ſir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Suppoſe I were Sir, what then?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I ſhould (as many upſtarts haue done) proue rich: for I beleeue you would make me your heire.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Is that part of your beliefe?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A principall poynt ſir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Renounce it then, for I beleeue you'l never be ſaved by't.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I am ſure I cannot looſe by't. I beleeue further, that many Knights, and ſome Ladies, were never of Gods making.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Of whoſe then, wagge?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Ile tell you: the Minters coyne Gold, Gold makes Heralds, Heralds makes Knights, and Knights ſtampe Ladies.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: And what doe Ladies?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: They liue not idle neither; they make ſome Knights, and marre many Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Ladies are good worke-women too, then?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Farre better then any Taylor: they'l make you an end of a ſuite, eſpecially a Court ſuite, when all the Taylors in a Countrey know not how to ſet a ſtitch in't.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I am of the beliefe you are a knaue, ſir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I had no faith, ſhould I ſay you were not?

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Well, what a Knaue?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: In a Knaues beliefe ſir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Becauſe in yours?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Doe you ſay't, and ile ſweare it, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: No more Boy, I am weary of your jeſts.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: That confirmes them to be good ſir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Your reaſon for that, ſir?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Becauſe travellers and lovers, are ſoone weary of goodneſſe.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Goodly ones indeed: but leaving this high-way of circumſtance; I ſent you for Manaſſes.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The learned Scribe attends you.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Will you fall off ſir?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Like an Apple at Michaelmas, without ſhaking. Exit.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Welcome Manaſſes: I haue preſent employment for thee, in which I muſt borrow—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Pardon me Madam, I learned of my Lord, to lend nothing without ſecuritie and pawnes.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: 'Tis not money (Manaſſes) but counſell and furtherance that we deſire.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Good counſell is worth good money Madam.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt bee well conſidered; there's twenty Crownes in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay Madam, this hand is like a fellow that takes every thing in jeſt; if you be in earneſt, let me feele it here: So Lady, now betwixt earneſt and jeſt, if your Will be ready drawne, before your friend delivered as your deed, and put me in truſt to execute it.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Take it this, in a word honeſt Sheepheard, and thy Lords daughter Madam Mopſa, are man and wife.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Man, and woman perhaps, but not man and wife: for though moſt women haue a will to bee Ladies, like my Lords wife; yet every Lady hath not wit to bee a wife, as my Lords Daughter. But what good can I doe in this?

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: O very much: for though they bee man and wife by oath and proteſtation, the chiefeſt ceremony of all; namely Mariage is yet unperformed, and hearing that you haue • ane orders.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: That I haue: I haue tane order for the making away of a hundred Maidenheads in my time, and not ſo few: but I am in the mind of you now, theſe two beagles, Dorus and Mopſa, haue runne themſelues breathleſſe in the chaſe of loue, you would ha' me couple them up in the leaſes of Matrimonie.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: You are in the right.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And you in the wrong, ile keepe your jeſt, but in any caſe take backe againe your earneſt: ile not purchaſe my Lords diſpleaſure with your gold.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Thy Lord ſhall never know't.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Oh ſir! though my M • hath but bad eyes, hee hath exceeding long eares: and though a Forrayner may play with a Citizens wooden Dagger, I would not wiſh any to jeſt with a Courtiers ſteeld Sword; tis ſeldome drawen but it drawes blood.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Tuſh man, be not ſo timerous, my credite ſhall countenance thee: bee not an Aſſe, make uſe of thy time: thy maſters ſervice is no heritage; the world knowes hee gets under the Duke, thou art a foole, and thou wilt looſe under him: there's a hundred Crownes for thee; tuſh man, thy betters will ſtraine curteſie with aleagence for a bribe

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Madam, could you to every one of theſe Crownes giue me a Kingdome?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I ſhould haue more ground then halfe the Kings in Chriſtendome: here's my hand, ile do't: my M. is my M. and I loue him; but my gold's my God, and I honour it: ile do't; the time and place?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Soone in the evening at Adonis Chapell. Art reſolute?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: As your Adamant: thinke you 'twas feare made me keepe out? no twas hope of theſe flattering ſweet lipt d • abs. I feare to marry my Ladies daughter? no nor to goe to bed with her neither, Why, I haue counterfeited his hand and ſeale. Hee has beene content with mee, to come neerer to him, at his entertainement of the laſt Embaſſadour, when hee was heate with drinking of healths. As I led him to his Chamber, I nimd • his Chaine, and drew his Purſe, and next morning perſwaded him he lo • t it in the great Chamber at the Revels. Hee puts me in truſt with his whole eſtate: he buyes Maners, I purchaſe Farmes: he builds houſes, I plucke downe Churches: he gets of the Duke, and I of the Commons: he beggers the Court, and I begger the whole Countrey.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Theſe are notable knaviſh courſes. What breeding haſt had?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Very good breeding ſir: My great Grandfather was a Rat-catcher, my Grandſier a Hangman, my father a Promooter, and my ſelfe an Informer.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Thou wert a knave by inheritance.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And by education too: but bawdy Informations growing ſtale, I gave up my cloake to a Broker, and crept into credite for a Gowne, and of Manaſſes a penurious Informer, I turned Coppy, and became Manaſſes, a moſt preciſe and illiterate expoſitor.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Were you a Reader then?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And a Writer too Bullie, I ſet ſome of my Pariſhioners wives ſuch coppies, as their husbands might caſt their caps at it, but could never come neere.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: But and you us'd ſuch a high and elevate ſtile, your auditories low and humble underſtandings ſhould never crall over't.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Tuſh, I could faſhion the body of my diſcourſe fit to the eare of my auditory: for to caſt Eloquence amongſt a company of Stinkards, is all one as if a man ſhould ſcatter pearle amongſt the hoggiſh animals ecliped Swine: no, I had paraphraſticall admonitions of all ſorts; Some againſt couetous Land-lords, and that would I ſquirt amongſt beggarly Tennants; Some againſt Vſurers, and that would I throw in at Priſon Grates amongſt prodigall Bankroutes; Some againſt the pride of the Court, and that honies the eare of the Citizen; Some againſt the fraud of the city, and that's cake and cheeſe to the Countrey; Some againſt Proteſtants, and that plumps the laſy Catholike; againſt Papiſt and Proteſtant, and that fattens the ranke-witted Puritan; againſt Papiſt, Puritan, and Proteſtant, and that tickles the eare of the luxurious Athieſt.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Why you never light upon any Athieſts, doe you?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Oh very many.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: In the countrey perhaps, and the out-skirts of the City.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: In the very boſome of the City, and by your leave, here and there one in the Court too: But wee fit em all; for indeed wee wandring Lights have (as other Tradeſ-men have) Commodities of all ſorts and prices.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: How doe they come by them?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: As many doe by Offices, ſteale into them ere the Duke be aware of em. Some buy em at Booke-ſellers ſtalls, but the beſt they beſpeake of Poets.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Mee thinkes Poets of all men ſhould not edify, they are ſo envious.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
One to another, to nobody elſe: a Proud Poet is for all the world like a Puncke in requeſt, covetous of many Clients, when ſhe
hath more then ſhee can handſomely play off: You ſhall have ſome Poet (Apolloes Vicar eſpecially) write you a Comicall, Paſtorall, Tragicall, Muſicall hiſtory in Proſe, will make the Auditors eyes runne a water like ſo many water-ſpouts; I had one of them my ſelfe, and your eares bee in caſe, Ile give you a taſt on't; his argument was fet out of the Poem called, The loſt ſheepe, and thus it is.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Prithee be briefe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay peace, and it were in place where you might wake the beſt men in the pariſh, for commonly they ſleepe the beginning, becauſe they love not diviſion: but to the loſt Sheepe. Beloved, you muſt imagine this Sheepe was a Sheepe, a loſt Sheepe, a Sheepe out a the way; but my deare Flocke and loving Sheepe, whom like a carefull Shepheard I have gathered together, with the whiſtle or pipe, as it were of mine Eloquence, into this Fold of peacefull Communitie, doe not you ſtray, doe not you flie out, doe not you wander, doe not you looſe your ſelves; but like kinde Sheepe and valiant Rams, I ſpeake to you the better part and head of my Flocke: As I ſay, you ſhall ſee the valiant Rammes turne all their hornes together, and oppoſe themſelves againſt the Wolfe, the hungry Wolfe, the greedy Wolfe, the Lambes-devouring Wolfe, the Wolfe of all Wolfes, to defend their Eawes and young ones. Durſt you lay all your heads together, and with the hornes of your Manhood defend your Families, your owne Wives, and your neighbours children: Was not this ſtinging geere?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: A good Sheepiſh admonition.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The fitter for my audience; while you live have a care to fit your audience.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Thou ſpeakeſt like a Chriſtian, prithee what Religion art of?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How many ſoever I make uſe of, Ile anſwer with Piavano Orlotto the Italian; I profeſſe the Dukes onely.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: What's his reaſon for that?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: A very ſound reaſon: for ſayes hee, I came raw into the world, and I would not willingly goe roſted out: ſo cloſe up the ſtomacke of your diſcourſe with that dry anſwer, and every man about his buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: You'l be mindfull of tomorrow night?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: As your Lawyer of the Tearme, or your Landlord of the Quarter-day.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Why ſo: the mettle I muſt forge my plot on, lies a warming in the furnace of my braine; and I muſt faſhion it inſtantly, for feare it burſt vvith heat. Giue my conceit way, for here comes one muſt helpe to proportion it.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: How now Demetrius, what wind hath blowne up this ſtorme of melancholy? thy countenance was not wont to bee thus cloudy; Whence proceeds this ſudden alteration?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: From mine owne hard fortune my Lord, that my ill-ſtard nativitie ſhould continue thus oppoſite.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Art croſt in a ſute at Court? or what's the matter? ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Ile acquaint your Honour: I hope no other eare overheares us. Vnder Dianaes Oake I found an inſcription upon a ſtone, which told me, that wealthy Ariſtomones ſometimes brought into Arcadia, had there under hid a maſſie ſumme of treaſure.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Vnder Dianaes Oake? Dorus ſhall haue my daughter Mopſa: no more words on't, and thou loveſt me Dorus: ſmother thy golden hopes a day or two; thou ſhalt haue Mopſa, but • le haue all the Gold, then marry my daughter to ſome great man, though he be poore, tis the faſhion: Ile bee nobly allied what ere it coſt me: ſhalt bee my Sonne in law Dorus. haue an eye to the Princeſſe, fall cloſe to my daughter Mopſa,

lg.l: Court her and ſpare not: now begins the ſport,
Kiſſe her, doe, kiſſe her; thou ſhalt pay ſweetly for't:
I can gull you, know what faire words can doe,
I'me an old Knaue, and a young Courtier too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: So, ſo; how violently hee devoures his bane, and ſteales himſelfe into the order of Gullerie: me thinkes I ſee how betwixt hope and feare he ſweats in his practice, and like a fooliſh dreamer, caſts how to lay out his wealth before it comes in▪ So much for him: Now to my Lady Beauty his wife; and as the Devill would ha • t, here ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Miſo.
sp.p: Dorus, how now Dorus? What time a day is't with you?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What time a day ſoever it bee with me, tis ſleeping time with my Lord, I am ſure of that.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: Sleeping time Dorus, what doſt thou meane by that?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Nay nothing, hee is troubled with a kind of malady called Inſurrectio carnis.

sp.speaker: Miſo.
sp.p: How, a diſh of Crevices? nay and that be the worſt, good enough; I am glad a falls to Fiſh, for hee was given to Fleſh a late too too bad.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Maſſe I thought as much, for I ſaw him goe a angling.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: I hold my Ladiſhip, to ſome ſtru •… et.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Life a jealouſy, I think you are a witch, twas ſo indeed.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: Nay I thought as much; he was wont to kiſſe me, and doe all • indneſſe a man could doe, till he came to the Court, and now he will not lye with me for ſooth, and why? tis the Court faſhion: he will not love me, and why? tis the Court faſhion: I muſt not come neere him at his downe- • ing, nor his up-riſing, &c. And this bee the Court faſhion, would I were an honeſt woman of the Countrey againe, be Courtiers who liſt: I, I, Dorus, I tell thee in teares, hee hath not dealt by me as a husband ſhould doe.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Tis nothing to mee, I cannot doe withall Madam, would I could.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: Yes marry mayſt thou Dorus; thou mayſt, and ſhalt doe withall too and thou wilt: but as thou lookeſt to enjoy my daughter Mopſa, acquaint me with the old Foxes ſtarting hole.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: That's paſt my cunning, the old Foxe has more holes then one to hide's head in: But not to goe long about the buſh with you.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: No good Dorus, I doe not love a man ſhould goe long about my Buſh: what is ſhe for a woman?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I know not what ſhe is for a wom • n, marry I feare ſhee's little better then a whore for your husband; hearke in your eare, ſhee's Manaſſes wife.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: Manaſſes wife? marry fire maſter gunner, a Puritan turnd Punke: Gods my precious. Ile ſlit her noſe, as I am a Lady will I; is ſhe the party you wot on?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes faith Madam, ſhee is the Mare the man rid on.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: Ile ſpoyle their ſport, ſaddle my Mule there, have an eye to the Princeſſe; ſhaltha my daughter, an't be but to ſpite him withal, faith Fox Ile ha you out of your hole, or Ile fire you out.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Nay that will doe no good, but for your owne good Madam, take heed you doe not ſcold.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: Why, may not a Lady ſcold Dorus?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Scold? O in no caſe, twill marre a Ladies beauty cleane, and make her looke as hard-favoured as any ordinarie woman.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: Godamercy for that Dorus, Ile not loſe my beauty for twenty on em: ſaddle my Mule, bring mee my chopping-knife, Ile geld the lecherous Goat, and mince his Trull as ſmall as herbs to the pot. This is not ſcolding Dorus, is't?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No this is tollerable.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: Nay then I care not, ſaddle my Mule I ſay, let her pray God her feeling be good, for as I am a Lady, Ile not leave her an eye to ſee withall, and yet I will not ſcold neither.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Oh take heed of that at any hand. So, ſo, ſo; now it beginnes to quicken, me thinkes I ſee already how ſhe runnes atilt at the wenches eyes, calls the Mayd Bawd, the woman whore, and her husband Lecher; and when all comes to all, like an Iriſh wolfe, ſhe barkes at her owne ſhaddow; but committing her and her Aſſe to their wild-gooſe chace, now to my ſweet-heart Mopſa, for ſhee's all the blocke's laſt in my eye to ſtumble on; and God bleſſe my wits, for the foole haunts me.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Dorus, where's my Father Dorus?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Your father? O my deere Mopſa.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Nay now you flowt me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Flout you? Oh the faire heavens! but this 'tis for a man to caſt away himſelfe in violence of paſſion, and extremity of ſighs, on a piece of beauty that cares not for him, but it is the trickes of you all.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Trickes? no as God mend mee; and I ſhould not have a husband till I got him with trickes, I ſhould leade Apes in hell: but faith tell me, doſt thou love me Dorus?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Doe I love you quoth ye? It cuts my very heart-ſtrings, doe I love you? why tis the onely marke my endeavours ſhoot at.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: If thou doſt not hit the marke then, thou art a very bungler: but where is my father?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why I have ſent him and your mother out of the way of purpoſe, and appoynted Manaſſes to meete us this evening at Adonis Chappell, in the Amazons aparrell, to marry us; I thinke theſe are ſignes I love you.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I but you jeſt, I doubt you will not marrie me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Will you meet me there?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: As I am a virgine I will.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And come with an intent to marry me?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: As I hope to be a wife I will.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You muſt take heed you keepe our purpoſe cloſe.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: As I did the loſſe of my Maydenhead.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why haue you loſt it then?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Many a deare day agoe, yet I told no body on't but my Mother and our Horſe-keeper, and they ſay I am nere the worſe maid for that, and I can keepe my owne counſell, as I hope I ſhall; but will you meet me ſoone?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Iuſt in the mid-way, as Tilters doe.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Ile goe afore and ſtay, but doe not deceiue me, and you doe, ile ſhew my Fathers Horſe-keeper all as God mend me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: So tria ſequuntur tria, now am I rid of a triumuirie of fooles, and by their abſence haue wonne a free acceſſe to an eſcape.

lg.l: If my Liſanders hope proue like to this,
This night ſhall crowne us Monarches of our bliſſe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: No more of theſe delayes ſweet Madam, your loue hath broken day oft with my expectance, I dare giue it truſt no longer.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: I confeſſe it my Liege, and like a ſpent Deare, not able to maintaine longer flight, I caſt my ſelfe downe breathleſſe at your loues mercy: yet I beſeech your Majeſtie, let not your eager deſires practiſe any preſent violence upon my yeelding chaſtitie: 'twas only poſſeſſion of my loue you had in chace, which with convenient time and place purchaſed, I put your grace in full poſſeſſion of.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Although thy breath bee never but muſicall, yet it never raught the ſtring of true happineſſe till now: and to approue thy heart ſets hand to thy word, appoint the time.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Then this preſent evening (and yet my Virgine blood is aſhamed to conſent to the betraying of my modeſtie) meet me at Adonis bower, where ile make tender of ſubdued chaſtitie to your high Majeſtie, as my firſt and moſt victorious conquerour.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: By my Imperiall Globe, and hope of thoſe joyes, thy preſence ſhall bring to enrich mee with, Ile meet thee, and make thee Queene over the moſt ſubmiſſe Captiue that ever loue tooke priſoner.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: If you deceiue me—

lg.l: Not except warme life,
Deceiue my veines of their innatiue heat.
Then haſte ſlow time, exchange thy leaden feete
For Hermes wings till I my faire hopes meet.
But lockt once in the armes of my delight,
Cloath all the world in an eternall night.
And ſteed of morning when the Sun ſhould riſe,
They ſhall ſee two in my Zelmanes eyes.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: So farewell thought I, I haue prepar'd you a Zelmanes anſwerable to your expectation.

lg.l: Then triumph in thy will, and let thy thoughts
Proclaime a Iubilee: my teeming hopes
Are now deliver'd of a gratious birth,
Which I haue chriſtened, opportunitie,
Vnto whoſe ſhrine in honour of this day,
My thoughts ſhall hold a monethly ſacrifice.
Loue grant Demetrius meet the like ſucceſſe,
Our paines are crown'd with double happineſſe.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Only our diſguiſes hold firme, but all other attempts meet untimely deaths, even in their cradles.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: What and we ſhould acquaint the Ladies with our intents?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: 'Twould argue a kind of cowardiſe in our wits, that haue ſuch ſuſpectles admittance to their preſence, as this diſguiſe hath purchaſed us, wee ſhould not haue that abilitie of inventure to entangle them in their owne ſecuritie.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Well howſoever, wee muſt not dwell long determining for the libertie of ſtay with Dametas, who out of his covetous diſpoſition in detayning our reward allowed us, the eldeſt day of our licenc't aboad at Court, is run out.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.p: Tis very true, and for my part, Ile rather goe home with a private repulſe, then managing any unlikely attempt, become ſufferer under a publicke diſgrace.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p:
That's my very thought, yet that our ſecond arrivall bee not altogether empty of employment, lets practiſe ſomething upon Dametas, and acquaint the world with his coward baſeneſſe; in which, hee not onely detracts from his maſters bountie, but looke how as a Conduit head or maſter-ſpring that is poyſoned, doth his
beſt, to infect the whole body of the Court, with the leaproſie of his covetouſneſſe.

sp.speaker: Iul
sp.p: There's no action of his begetting can be ſaid to bee truely honourable.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: How can they when their Father is a mungrell? the Duke out of his honourable bounty commanded him to reward our travels with • 00. Crownes: and now after two moneths attendance, and enforc't delayes, In which time an ordinary Petitioner might haue ſpent the valew of the reward, hee packs us off with fiftie Crownes, his excuſe being that his maſter hath forgot us, and what he doth, is of his owne bounty, as if the Moone ſhould brag ſhee gaue the world light, when all the luſter ſhe hath, comes from the heat of the Sunne.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Should his villanies be ſuffered to proſper, they would grow to ſuch height, as the Dukes authority ſhould haue much trouble to prune them.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: To prevent which, his Majeſty ſhall haue private note of it, knew we in whoſe truſt to conduct it.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Tis an office very few dare undertake, he is ſo riveted to the Dukes good opinion.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Lies there no jarre twixt none of the Nobilitie and him, what ſay you of Zelmane?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: The gallant Amazon: you could not haue caſt your choice fitter, for her honourable minde maintaines deadly feud againſt his baſe proceedings; and here ſhee comes, attended by Dameta's ſervant, lets waite on opportunity.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Liſander.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Demetrius.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Liſander and Demetrius? ſtand cloſe, of my life wee are come to the birth of ſome notable knavery.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: How blowes the winds of our hopes?

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Faire to the poynt of our expectation, I haue made away the Duke and the Dutcheſſe.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: How made away them? poyſon'd them?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p:
With a confection of loue, which I haue ſo tempred with faire promiſes, as their mindes are in loues haven already, Videlicet in Adonis bower, where this evening I haue given them my word
to meet them; but I haue ſo caſt it, that Manaſſes ſhall meet them in my ſteed.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: 'Twill be a rare Scene of mirth, to heare what coſtly diſcourſe they'l beſtow upon the foole in thy outſide.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Doe you heare that?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Yes, thanke loue and my eares, but liſt the concluſion.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: I haue cleard the way to Violetta, but what order haſt thou • ane with thy burbolts, Dametas, Miſo, and amorous Mopſa?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Shot them away, at three ſeverall markes, yet ſo conveyed it, that in the end they ſhall all meet at Adonis Chappell.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: This project cannot but bring forth ſome notable deceit.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: My hopes ſhould want of their will, and it doe not—

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Now we haue made a ſmooth paſſage to our eſcape, how ſhall we convey our loves out of the Iland?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I haue determined of that ſir, and better to effect, my boy this time hath caſt ſuch a baite of knavery to the two Captaines, Kalander and Philanax, as we may paſſe without ſuſpition.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: But how for tranſportation.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I am furniſht of that too, you remember the two Lacedemon intelligencers.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Now what of us?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Hold my life, we ſhall be put in this Scene of Gullery.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Oh in any caſe.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: For the loue of Cupid doe, inquiry is paſt, lets take our entrance, and paſſe over the ſtage like mutes, to furniſh out a ſhow.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: And ſee occaſion like a kind wench preſents them in the very inſtant, my honeſt friend welcome, haue you not your diſpatch with a letter to Lacedemon.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Madam we haue, and ſtay onely to take our leaues of your Ladiſhip, and know what ſervice your honour will command.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: You haue my thankes, for the truth is, I muſt commit buſines of much import unto your truſt, and to prevent much circumſtances take my word, your are not ignorant of the Kings generall challenge.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: About his daughters.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: You underſtand mee, with theſe few crownes receiue my mind, which is to convey the two Ladies, whom we in theſe diſguiſes haue wonne to Lacedemon.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Were we but confirm'd of your eſtates.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Wee'l giue you ſufficient aſſurance of that, and the Princeſſes themſelues ſhall confirme it.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Wee craue no better Madam, but ſhall we not haue your honours company?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: No: having brought them aboard, wee'l make returne to the Duke, to let him underſtand we ſtole not our prizes but wonne them manfully at the poynt of wit.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: A noble reſolution.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: His foile will appeare the more palpable, and your conqueſt the more applauſible, where ſhall we receiue the Ladies?

sp.speaker: De •• .
sp.p: Be that our care, but on your liues be heedfull of their▪ ſafeties.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: More then of our owne my Lord.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Enough, whilſt you attend weele to the Duke, and play all Guls or none.

lg.l: All Guls indeed ſince you had follies vvhip,
No Guls, to all Guls, fooles loue fellowſhip.

sp.speaker: Miſo.
sp.p: Looke well to mine Aſſe there, Lord how I ſweat with anger; this ſames the houſe ſure, and now like a wiſe Lady let me count my hurts, and ſee how I ſhall be reveng'd: it ſhall be ſo, ile haue them both carted, and Manaſſes ſhall goe afore like a whif • er, and make way with his hornes: where be theſe whores? open the doore, where bee theſe panders? O that I vvere not a Lady, I could ſcold like a butter-vvhore.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Whoſe there a Gods name? Lord for his mercy is the vvoman mad?

sp.speaker: Miſo.
sp.p: Yes I thanke yee fo • 't▪ horne mad, vvhere's your companion, vvhere's the old leacherous Goat my husband? open the doore I ſay.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ieſus for thy mercy ſake, Madam vvhat doe you vvant?

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: What do I vvant? the chiefe implement a vvoman ſhould haue; I vvant that as a vvoman cannot be vvithout, I meane my husband I vvant.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Your husband? I ſavv him not as I am an honeſt vvoman.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: Not as you are an honeſt, ſo I thinke, but as you are an arrant vvhore you did, you muſt haue your Creviſhes vvith a pox, cannot Citty Maunchet and freſh God ſerue your turne, but you muſt haue Court Cake-bread and Creviſhes vvith a vengeance? but come giue me my husband, or Ile haue him ou • of the fleſh on thee, and yet I vvill not ſcold neither.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Pray madam ha' patience: vvhat ſhould your husband doe here?

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p:
That vvhich he ſhould doe at home vvith his vvife, and he
were worth his eares.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Lady I protect I doe not know him.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: Not know him? thou lieſt in every ve • e i'th heart, thou lyeſt thou knoweſt him, and as Adam knew Eue thou knoweſt him, he hath beene as in ward with thee, as ever he was with me, he hath, by his owne confeſſion he hath, and thou denieſt it, thou lieſt in thy throat like a Puritanicall whore as thou art, O that I were a butter who • e for an houre I might ſcold a little.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Madam they are no honeſt men that bring theſe tales to you.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: Men bring tales to me? I de • ie thee in thy guts, I defie thee. men bring tales to mee? thou takeſt me to bee one of thine owne Church doſt? they are no honeſt men that bring tales to thee and ha' wiues of their own, & my husbands one of them, go thy waies now.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I beſeech you Madam doe but heare me.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: Heare thee? I haue heard too much of thee, too too much, too much, where's my husband? bring forth my husband, ile teach him to put a difference betwixt Ioan and my Lady I hold him ten pound on't, and yet I will not ſcold neither, and I had beene an old hag paſt teaming, as his whore is a puritan, it had bin ſomewhat, but being a woman of Gods making, & a Lady of his own, and wearing mine owne haire which is much in a Lady of my ſtanding I can tell you, to uſe me thus, fleſh and blood cannot endure it, let me come in, open the doore let me come in, O that I were any vile thing in the world but a Lady that I might ſcold a little.

div.stage: Enter Kalander and Philanax, Demetriu's Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: So, ſo, ſo, take your places, for this ſame bald pated oake is the ſtage, where yee ſhall ſee the part of a doting foole performed by an old man and a young wench.

sp.speaker: Kal.
sp.p: Who worſhipfull Dametas?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The ſame man.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Hath he no fellow Acters in his moſt lamentable, comicall, hiſtoricall, tragicall, muſicall, paſto • a'l?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: None that require any mouthing but his Aſſe and himſelfe, marry then he has Signior Mattocke, a very ſharpe ſatyricall humoriſt, and Mounſier le ſpade, but he goes ſomewhat more bluntly to his buſines, yet heele ſerue for mutes, and as good as the beſt to furniſh out the ſtage.

sp.speaker: Kal.
sp.p: But dares Dorus being but Dametas ſervant ſo abuſe his mad maſter thus groſly.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O Lord Sir, there haue beene ſerving men haue done their Maſters farre greater abuſe, yet had their wiues conceald it, their eares ſhould never haue beene acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Is that a faſhion in requeſt?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Altogether ile aſſure you, but obedience, Gentlemen the Scene begins.

div.stage: Enter Dametas, with mattocke and ſpade.

sp.speaker: Kal.
sp.p: Pray God it be good he ſtayes ſo long, Ridiculous enough, and good enough.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: So, ſtand Aſſe, ſtand gentle Aſſe.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.p: What Countrey-man is his Aſſe, he ſpeakes ſo familiarly to him?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A'th Citie breed, marry hee picks up his living ath burs and nettles that grow about the Court gate.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Be in readineſſe good mattocke, play thy part ſweet ſpade, let mee ſee; Dianaes oake? I held Dianaes oake divine, true pure gold, honeſt Dorus, fortunate Dametas.

sp.speaker: Kal.
sp.p: An excellent comoedian, what life he puts into his part.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: So, by thy leaue ſtone, by thy patience honeſt ſtone, the very gravell ſavours of treaſure, this ſame's the bed-chamber of my Lady Pecu • ia, and ſee, ſee ſome of her golden haires, more, more, more yet divine tree, pure gold, honeſt Dorus, fortunate Demetrius, ſoftly, ſoftly, not too faſt, let me not devoure my content too greedily, leſt like a cormorant I take a ſurfet on't.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Oh take heed of that maſter in any caſe.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Pure mettle, excellent gold: but let me ſee now, I ſhall by computation haue ſome three millions of 'em, • ſome three or foure mi • lions, how ſhall I employ them to make the moſt profit of them

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: That would be knowen indeed.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Ile put out one million to uſe, after the rate of ſeven ſcore to the hundreth: and yet I wont, no fie, for then you will haue my humour brought ath ſtage for a vſurer; to prevent with ſcandalous report, ile put it into my Scribe-majors hand, & he ſhall dea • e for me.

sp.speaker: Kal.
sp.p: There's a ſimple cloake▪ to cover his villany.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Tis a very ſhort one: and paſſing ſl • te to hide his knavery.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: It cannot chuſe but be ſeene through.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p:
An other million ile lay to beſlow in Offices. I will haue wealth, or ile rake it out ath kennels elſe, chimnies ha' ſmoakt for't already, and now ile deale upon ſea-cole and ſalt, now, now, now, it comes, ſweet gold, honeſt Dorus, fortunate Demetrius, divine gold, how, how ſhal I adore thee? O let me doe the homage of my knees: now, now, for the tongue of a Poet, though I hate poetry worſe then • ny of the ſeven deadly ſins, I could wiſh my ſelfe a Poet for ſome
houre, to write a Poem in the praiſe of my divine miſtreſſe; and ſee he very bed wherein her divinitie is lodged: happy, happy, thrice happy Dametas, now like an o're joyd lover, let mee open the ſheets of my heavenly miſtreſſe with reverence, ſo with humble reverence, and like a bluſhing lover that puts out the light ere he preſumes to touch the bed of his loue, ſo let me darken the candles of my body, mine eyes, and firſt bleſſe my hands with touching, next enrich mine eares with hearing, and laſtly make happy my eyes with ſeeing, and let them convey the joy downe into the boſome of my thoughts by degrees, ſoftly by degrees.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee Aſſe make ſuch a ceremonious preparation?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Be not offended ſweet mi • treſſe that I preſume to touch.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: A fooles head of your owne.

sp.speaker: Kal.
sp.p: Has a beene at any coſt of all this invocate for a coxcombe and a bell.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Beſhrow my judgement but he deſerues it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: And his deſert were nere ſo much, he could but beare away the bell, and ſo you ſay he doth.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: A coxcombe and a bell, oh indignity: damnable oake, vile and evill accurſt Dorus, unfortunate Dametas; Diana I tell thee thou art no honeſt goddeſſe to uſe a Gentleman thus. Whats here a writing, your helpe good ſpectacles, lend me your helpe good ſpectacles, ſome comfortable newes good ſpectacles:

lg.l: Who hath his hire, hath well his labours plac't,
Earth thou didſt ſeeke, and ſtore of earth thou haſt.
He that vaine hopes purſues for loue of pelfe,
Shall looſe his vvits and likely find himſelfe.
Then thinke thy paines revvarded vvell,
Thou broughſt the foole, beare backe the bell:
Of other matters vvhat enſues,
Adonis bovver ſhall tell thee nevves,

sp.p: Villanous poetry, I am made a flat foole by poetry; But though I can doe them no▪ further diſgrace, my fatall curſe, A vvronged gentlemans fatall curſe dvvell ever upon them: Diana here me, and let my vvords find gratious acceptance.

sp.speaker: Kal.
sp.p: Hide your heads, the terrible curſe comes like a ſtone upon you.

lg.l: Rancor, ſpite, malice, hate, and all diſaſters,
Strengthen my faith againſt all poetaſtors.
May their intents though pure as chriſtall glaſſes,
Be counted falte and capitall Treſpaſſes,
O may their lines and labour'd induſtrie,
Though worthy of Apollo's plaudite,
The cleereſt thought in loyalty excelling,
Be by ſome Dor preſented for libelling;
When they have writ a Scene, in which their braines
Have dropp'd their deereſt ſweets, and their ſwolne veines
Emptied the Conduit of their pureſt ſpirit,
As they ſtand gaping to receive their merit,
In ſtead of Plaudities, their chiefeſt bliſſes,
Let their deſerts be crown'd with mewes and hiſſes:
Behind each poſt, and at the Gallery corners,
Sit empty gulls, ſlight fooles, and falſe Informers;
Let ſome ſlye Foxe out of diſcretions embers,
Terme them the Lands unneceſſary members;
And like the Deere, when they have ſpent their breath
To make Kings ſport, let them be torne to death,
Even by their friends; 'twould ſet my thoughts a twanging,
Might I but • e one of them goe to hanging.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: A paſſing ſtrange curſe, and no queſtion he has travelled farre for ſome of the times.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: He muſt travell further that findes any reaſon in't.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: No matter for reaſon, there's rime enough if that be good.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: Some of it is no better then it ſhould bee, or my judgement deceives me.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: Sure hee had ſome reaſon to make this rime, and a man could picke it out.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: Rather then Ile bee counted inquiſitive, mine eares ſhall content themſelves with the rimes only, and leave the reaſon to the ſcanning of Poets, whom it more neerely concernes.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: But where's the wag that invited us to this banquet of mirth, ſhrunke in the wetting?

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: I were a rare jeſt now, if whil'ſt the Boy keeps us here in expectation of Dametas gullery, his Maſter has made an eſcape with the Dukes daughters.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: That, or ſome knavery elſe upon my life: I had the boy in ſhrewd ſuſpicion at the firſt.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: And this his ſudden and ſtoln departure confirms it currant.

lg.l: Then we are ſped, for in ſuſpitions face
I ſee ſome ſubtle ſtratagem in chace.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Will your Ladiſhip beleeve me now? nay and I ſay't your worſhip may ſwear't, though I have but a (poore as to ſay) hole of mine owne, I hope the ſpirits have more denomination over mee, then to make it a common Slaughter-houſe of carnallity, where every Iacke may command fleſh for his money.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: No more wordes ſweete woman, I confeſſe I was in the wrong, this is not the hole the Foxe hides his head in, and therfore for the love of woman-hood conceale mine errours; for howſoever I complain'd, tis thy forehead akes, thy temples have the terrible blow as they ſay, thy husband is a bad man.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: My husband?

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: I, I, good woman, thy husband; hee is, as I ſay, a fleſhly member, and I feare he has overcome the fooliſh thing my daughter.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Your daughter? Ile ſlit her noſe by this light, and ſhe were ten Ladies, twas not for nothing my husband ſaid hee ſhould meete her this Evening at Adonis Chappell: but and I come to the Godſpeed on't, Ile tell em on't ſoundly.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: I doe good woman, tell em on't and ſpare not, but in any caſe doe not ſcold.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why, may not a Gentlewoman ſcold in a good caſe?

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: I know not what a Gentlewoman may doe in a good caſe, but a Lady muſt not in any caſe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Though I may not ſcold, I may tell em roundly on't I hope.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: That you may doe law.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And Ile not bee mealely mouth'd I warrant em: will you beare me company to the Chappell Madam?

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: With all my heart Miſtris: What Dorus hath given me, Ile give my friend, No foole to company.

div.head: ACTVS V. SCENA I.
div.stage: Enter the King at Adonis Bower.

lg.l: FArewell bright Sunne, thou lightner of all eyes,
Thou fall'ſt to give a brighter beame to riſe.
Each tree and ſhrub weare trammells of thy haire,
But theſe are wiers for none but Kings to weare,
And my rude tongue, ſtriving to blaze her forth,
Like a bad Arts-man, does diſgrace her worth:
But here's the place, upon this Chriſtall ſtreame,
Where Citharea did unyoake her teame
Of ſiluer Doves to interchange a kiſſe
With young Adonis, ſhall I meet my bliſſe?
The gentle minutes crown'd with chryſtall flowers,
Loſing their youths, are growne up perfect houres,
To haſten my delight: The baſhfull Moone,
That ſince her dalliance with Endymion
Durſt never walke by day, is under ſaile,
In ſtead of ſheetes has ſpread her ſilver vaile,
Each gliding Brooke and every buſhy tree,
Being tipt with ſilver, weare her livery;
And the dimme night, to grace our amorous warres,
Hath ſtucke nine Spheares full of immortall ſtarres,
In ſtead of pearles; the way on which ſhe treads
Is ſtrew'd with chryſtall deaw and ſilver beades: Enter Dutcheſſe.
She comes, her feet make muſicke with the ground,
And the chaſt aire is raviſht with the ſound,
My ſoule flies forth to meet her: hell, my wife,
Her preſence like a murtherer drives the life
Out of my pleaſures breſt, her jealous eye
Envies the heaven of my felicity.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Zelmane, or my husband? life, or hate?

lg.l: What makes old Autumne out a bed ſo late?
That ſnow ſhould goe a wooing to the Sunne,
When one warme kiſſe workes her confuſion!
I have the jeſt, ſuſpition that keepes
Court in my husbands thoughts, ſeeing my Love
Elect this walke, hath brought him after him.
She dogs her ſure, and ſhe to ſhake her off
Hath tane ſome other walk, Ile place mine care
In diſtance of her will.
Could I but heare the innocent delivery of his breath,
'Twould be a ſecond Iubile of mirth.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Here comes my Love.

lg.l: Your Love? Alas poore Duke,
Your forward hopes will meet a barren ſpring,
My Sunne appeares.
Fie, your love ſpeakes too loud,
Your Sunne's eclips'd, you doate upon a cloud.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: See how his armes, like precious Phoenix wings, Spread to imbrace me.

lg.l: Now the Cuckow ſings;
Thoſe amorous armes doe make a golden ſpace
To hug a Duke.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: But Ile fill up the place.

lg.l: Thoſe fingers tipt with curious Porphery,
Staining Pigmalions matchleſſe imag'ry,
Like amorcus twins all of one mother • urſt,
Contend in courteſy who ſhould touch me firſt.
Should touch me firſt; their ſtrife is undertooke,
To twine a young Bay, not a ſtooping Oake.
Young Bay? ſtale jeſt, that a dry ſapleſſe rinde
Should hold young thoughts, and a licentious mind:
Were ſhe but gone now.
Were the Duke away,
My hopes had got the better of the day.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: This is Adonis Chappell, I wonder they come not; though I beare but a litle learning about me, and a few good clothes, I would not wiſh em to make Balams Aſſe of me: for though many fooles take no felicity but in wearing good clothes (though they bee none of their owne) I have a further reach in me.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: I could ban my ſtarres.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: 〈…〉 my fate.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: That croſſe me thus.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Makes me unfortunate.

lg.l: Alas good Lady, how her pretty feet
Labour to find me.
Such blacke events.
Darken her ſelfe.
That in the boſome of ſome foggy cloud
I might imbrace my love.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: That my hopes ſhould meet

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: O would the friendly night

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Would the Moone loſe her light,

lg.l: But night is purblind,
To make a Duke a ſlave.
To make e Dutcheſſe
Wreſtle with amorous paſſions.
Life a ſpleene,
Could my rough breath like a temptſtuous wind,
Blow out heavens candles, leaue the world ſtarke blind,
That it might either haue no eyes to ſee,
Or uſe thoſe eyes it hath to pleaſure me.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Or uſe thoſe eyes it hath to pleaſure me?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Who would haue thought the cold had beene ſo good a muſician? how it playes upon my chaps? and maketh my teeth skip up and downe my mouth like a company of virginall Iacks, but I find ſmall muſicke in it, and Mopſa ſhould come now I could doe her little good, yet and ſhe were here, ſhe and I would haue about at cob-nut or at chery-pit, or ſome what to keepe our ſelues from idleneſſe, though ſhe be but a foole, the bable's good enough to make ſport withall in the darke, and that very word hath ſtarted her.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Whoſe there Manaſſes?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes Mopſa.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Plaine Mopſa, I might bee Madam Mopſa in your mouth, goodman—where's Dorus?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why? becauſe he will not be ſaid to make too much haſte to a bad bargaine, he is not come yet.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Not come? a peaſcod on him, but al's one, I thought at firſt he would make but a foole on mee.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Would you haue him mend Gods workemanſhip?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: But chuſe him, ſince he hath buld me with an vrchin, ile goe fetch Raph our Horſe-keeper; let him that got the calfe keepe the cow in a knaues name and he will, haue you your booke here?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No matter wench, I can do't well enough without booke.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Nay and yee can do't well enough your ſelfe, I care for neither of them both, but indeed I loue to haue a thing well done, for ſayes my mother, a thing once well done, is twice done, and I am in her mind for that up and downe.

lg.l: Whoſe with my Lord the Duke? it cannot be,
Mine eye would not conceale ſuch treachery.
Tis not the Dutcheſſe ſure, no it is amarous Ioue,
That ſeeing Zelmane paſſionate for loue,
Deſcends to comfort her; Ioue if there be
A powerfull Phoebus God of poetry,
In deare remembrance of faire Daphnes rape,
To winne my loue, lend me ſome ſtranger ſhape,
Such as your ſelues haue worne, that when your ſame
Is ſung by Poets, they may quote my name.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Sure tis my daughter.

lg.l: Daughter? how her eye
Cut out new formes, new ſhapes of jealouſie?
As ſure as death tis ſhe, for ſee they ſtand
Like amarous twins, in twiſted hand in hand,
Breaſt againſt breaſt, and that no joy be miſſing,
To heare diſcourſe, their lips keepe time with kiſſing,
Ile not endure't, impatience grow ſtrong,
And though a Prince, tell him he doth thee wrong.
Doe, prethee doe, this ſweetens all the reſt,
But here would be the elixar of the jeſt,
If whilſt we keepe each other at a bay,
A third ſhould come, and beare the hare away.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Villanous poetry, unchriſtian-like poetry, I am cozend of my gold by poetry, rob'd of my charge by poetry, made an apparant foole by poetry, villanous Oke, accurſt Dorus, unfortunate Dametas: whoſe there my daughter and with Zelmane? a wel-willer to Dorus, a favorite to poetry, and therefore enemy to Dametas, come hither Mopſa, a thy fathers bleſſing come not neare her: what Mopſa.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Yes, whoſe there? Dorus.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Confuſion a Dorus, I am thy miſerable father, didſt not ſee Hippolita?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: No by my troth not. Did yee not ſee Dorus?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Poxe of Dorus, I am undone Madam and thou telft me not of Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Poxe a Hippolita, I am a dumbe woman and you can tell me newes of Dorus.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I had rather ſee ten Doruſſes hanged, then looſe Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I had rather ſee ten fathers damn'd, then looſe my ſweet Dorus.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I ſhall run mad and I find not Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I ſhall run franticke and I find not Dorus.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Whats here? I ſhall run mad for Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: And I ſhall run franticke and I find not Doras, I hold my life we haue ſome Comoedy in hand, wee ſhall haue a full Scene, for here comes more Actors.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: As ſure as I am a ſinner to God Madam, that ſames he.

sp.speaker: Miſo.
sp.p: What with a brace of wenches, ifaith old brocke, have I •• ne you in the manner, is this the fruits of your lying alone, is this your Court cuſtome with a wannion? lend me thy knife, though I had neither houſe nor land to give em, Ile beſtow a whores marke betwixt you, and yet I will not ſcold neither.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: What a goodyer aile you mother, are you frampall, know you not your owne daughter?

sp.speaker: Miſo.
sp.p: Mopſa? O inſufferable wrong, make thine owne naturall child thy Bawd?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Here's an excellent patterne for wives to learne to ſcold by.

sp.speaker: Miſo.
sp.p: What Miſtreſſe Amazon? ha you ſuch a cocking ſpirit, honeſt women cannot keep their husbands at home for you? tis not for nothing now I ſee, that the Dutcheſſe lookes yellow on you, but Ile teare that painted whores face of yours, (by this light) and yet I will not ſcold neither.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Miſo.
sp.p: Ile mad you with a vengeance.

div.stage: The Duke and Dutcheſſe ſt. p both forth and reſtraine her.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Touch not the Prince.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: On your allegeance forbeare, what means this outrage, cannot our private walkes be priviledg'd from your wild contentions?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: How fares the Prince?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: How cheeres my good Zelmane?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Zelmane? No Gods my judge my • iege • am Manaſſes, miſerable Manaſſes▪ your husbands Scribe-major Madam.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Manaſſes?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: A foole.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: My m • n.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: And my deare h •• d •… a • ſweet love, what makeſt th •• here?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: M •… y worke for the Hang-man, and the Duke bee not the more mercifull.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: There's ſome deceipt in this: Dametas, where's Hippolita?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I, I, there's ſome knavery in this: Mopſa, where's Hippolita?

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.p: Doubtles ther • ſome villany in this: Mopſa, wher's Hipolita?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: There's no plaine dealing in this, Manaſſes, where's Dorus?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Anſwer directly, where's Hippolita?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Alas Madam I know not, whil'ſt I almoſt mel • ed my ſelfe with digging of gold in Diana's Oke, I left her in my wives charge.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: And whil'ſt I ran to Manaſſes, thinking to take my husband and his wife in the manner, I left Hippolita in my daughters chamber.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: And whil'ſt • came to Adonis chappel, to be toſt in my mariage blankets with Dorus, I left my litle dog Pearle picking dazies.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Who ſent you to Diana's Oake to dig gold?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Who ſent you to take your husband in Manaſſes houſe?

sp.speaker: Miſo.
sp.p: Dorus.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Who ſent you to Adonis Chappell?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Dorus.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: And who turn'd you into this ſhape?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: They that I feare have made Gulls of us all, Zelmane and Dorus.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: We are all ſimply gulld, and ſee where the S • n ſcarce halfe ready, skips from his Eaſterne bed, ſmiling at our gullery.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Come where's this luſty wit-maſter?

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: The Keeper of this Love-lotterie.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: This gallant Iuventus of foureſcore, that like my Ladie of the Lake, diſplayes againſt all commers.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: May a couple of plaine-witted Princes have a ſight of your prizes?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Where be theſe Ladies, ha? ha your wits had ſuch a skir miſhing, that the two Maids have loſt their heads in the conflict?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Heads? I and bodies too my Lord, and all at one ſhot, and which is worſe, our wits are ſo ſcattered with the terrible blow, that, to be plaine, we are ſcarce our owne men againe.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Then you had ſome knocking.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: So it appeares by the ſtorie my Lord.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: How ſay you my Lady, what Oule ſings out of that Ivy-buſh?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: VVas your wit Knighted in this laſt action?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am not ſuch a foole, I love my Lord, I am no Knight, I am Manaſſes, they made a plaine foole.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: The onely weare, for the guarded foole is out of requeſt: but faith my Liege, how did your oppoſites behave themſelves, did they winne the wenches faire at the point?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: At the very puſh of invention, and went off cleere untoucht.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: And could you draw no blood of their wits?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Not a drop.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Nor Dametas neither, nor Manaſſes?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Neither, to our diſgrace be it ſpoken, the carriage of this ſtratagem deſerves applauſe, and I hold it a credite to reſt captive to ſuch valiant conquerours.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: VVhy ſo be, I like a man that will confeſſe his errour.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: It merits commiſeration Madam and my Liege, not to detract from our worth: your eare, we two are the parties you wot on.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Were you the man?

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: No he was the man, marry I was the woman in the Moone, that made you walke all this laſt night like the man in the miſt, I could ſay ſomewhat to you Madam, as for Dametas and his man, let them ſtand like fooles as they are.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Can it be poſſible?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: No, no, we are Guls, innocent ſots, but lante tanta, the girles are ours we haue won them away to Dargiſon.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Come we haue won the conqueſt, and that's ſufficient.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: You are a Manaſſes tis not ſufficient: aha not Hercules for Iole, Ioue for Danae, Apollo for Daphne, Pan for Sirne; nay the whole packe of their piperly godheads could a diſcharg'd a ſtratagem with more ſpirit of all merit; an ambling nag and a downe a downe we haue borne her away to Dargiſon.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: 'Twas the moſt rareſt, divineſt, Metaphyſicalſt piece of invention, that—what ſay you my liege?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: I giue your deſerts their full merit, you haue gotten equality.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: All the wenches gaue you.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Alas • hat ſpirits under the Moone could haue detaind her, but know that her cherry red lip, a downe, a downe.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Truſt me but you haue deſerved high commendation.

sp.speaker: Iulio
sp.p: Your merit ſtood of the upper ſtaire of admiration.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Why thou haſt a pretty reliſh of wit now, that canſt ſee the broad eye of my deſert at a little hole of demonſtration.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Your deſert ſaue mee free, you haue done a moſt (to uſe your owne phraſe) Metaphyſicall peece of ſervice, but you had ſome helpe in't queſtionleſſe.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: I doe not thinke but the Ladies had ſome handin't.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: A finger, I confeſſe a finger by the hope of perſeverance, a very little finger.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: I thought as much by making of the jeſt.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: I cannot detract from the Ladies worth, for I know them for excellent worke-women.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Worke-women fit to make Taylors men.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p:
I by my faith doe I, nay your beſt taylors are arrant botchers to them, you ſhall haue a Lady make an end of a ſute, a Court
ſute, eſpecially when all the Taylors in a countrey know not how to ſet a ſtitch in't.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Some ordinary ſute perhaps.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Your beſt Court ſuits that are, are finiſht by Ladies, I haue knowen a ſuite my ſelfe lien a making and m • ring • , • , and fiue yeare together, and then a Lady hath diſpatcht it in a moneth with a wet finger, ſuch a finger might the Ladies haue in your plot.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Never wet a finger by this Sunne.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Then ſhe helpt you with one dry jeſt or another, but and we may be ſo bold: faith whereare the Ladies?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Sure enough I warrant you, ſome fooles now would haue kept them here, and haue bin guld on them againe, and laught at age, but to prevent all danger, we haue ſhipt them home for Lacedemon.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: To Lacedemon? your ſunne of wit ſhines but dimly in that me thinkes, to whoſe charge haue you truſted them?

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: To them we durſt, nay you muſt thinke we are no fooles,

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Fooles? nay deepe wit, and pollicy forbid.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: We had no ſooner their ſurpriſall, but we had diſguiſe ready, a ſhip ready, a couple of luſty friends ready, the Lacedemon Intelligencers.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Durſt you truſt ſuch pretious jewels in ſuch ruſty caskets?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Durſt? our health, our liues, why they were my tenants; nay you muſt thinke we ſifted them, we are no fooles in that neither.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: If in any thing your wits deſerue the bable tis in that.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: None but fooles would haue committed ſuch ineſtimable peeres to a couple of ſtrangers.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: And in a ſhip too.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: And under ſaile too.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: And unfurniſht of friends too.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: And without ſhipping to follow them too.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: You were no fooles in any thing but that, and in that not to flatter, you expreſſe the true ſhape of folly, and meerely merit the name of fooles.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: What will you ſay now when theſe fellowes ſurrender us our loues?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Weele diſcharge you and ſet their names downe for Guls in your ſteed.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: You knovv the Proverbe, vvhen the skie ſals vve ſhall haue Larkes.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: And vvhen you can bring proofe that vve are conſend of our Wenches vveele be the Woodcocks.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: VVhy then we have once ſpring'd a couple of woodcocks.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Doe you know theſe? who are the fooles now?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Hippolita?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: My Violetta?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: VVhat a ſtrange change is here▪

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Yes ſaith Gallants, you have very ſtrange carding and you knew all, but I hope you'l offer up your cards, and yield the ſet loſt.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Gulls?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: And abus'd? Ile loſe my life before Ile loſe my honour.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Honour and life before Ile loſe my love.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Nay Gentlemen, wee barre all violence; the liberty of our challenge was to all alike equally free, and ſince theſe by faire play have won em, it ſtands with our honour to ſee them peaceably poſſeſt of em, then ſurely take em, for though you weare the breeches, give us leave to ſtand a little.

lg.l: VVhy father, is't not time that we were ſped?
Tis a great charge to keep a Mayd ••• -head,
Loſe it we muſt, and to prevent ill courſe,
Better to giv't, then haue it tane perforce,
If you be pleas'd let envy doe her worſt,
Spit out her poyſon, or contain't and burſt.
VVelcome to all, to all a kind good-night,
They truely live, that live in ſcorne of ſpight.

div.p: DAVIDS DESIRE TO GO TO CHVRCH: as it was publiſhed in two Sermons in St Maries in Oxford.
The One the fift of November in the Afternoone to the Vniverſity 1609. the Other on Chriſtmas Day following to the Pariſhioners of that place.
By IOHN DAY Bachelour of Divinity, and one of the Fellowes of Oriell Colledge.

q.p: Audite vos Eccleſiam relinquences, & in domibus communibus diverſantes, miſerabilia pretioſi corporis fragmento, quòd preces ac vota in medio Ieruſalem reddere oportet, hoc eſt Eccleſiae Dei.

div.p: AT OXFORD, Printed by Ioſeph Barnes.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT WORSHIPFVL Mr Dr BLENCOW Provoſt of Oriell Colledge, the Fellowes, & Students there:
WITH THE RIGHT Worſhipfull, the Worſhipfull, and the reſt of the Pariſh of St Maries,

head.hi: GRACE BE WITH YOV and peace from Godour Father, & from the Lord Ieſus Chriſt.

div.head: THE EPISTLE Dedicatorie.
div.p:
RIGHT Worſhipfull, & you the reſt Beloved in our Lorde. That which the Apoſtle ſaid cō cerning Wiues of being ſubiect to their 1. Pet. 3. 1 Husbands that even they which obeyed not the word might without the word haue beene wonne by the converſation of the wiues, while they beheld their pure converſation which was with feare: may with good congruity be ſaid to Proteſtant-Chriſtians, of often frequē ting Church-Service, that even they which obey not the word (I meane
Roman-Catholickes) may without the word be wonne by the converſatiō of ſuch Proteſtants, while they be hold our pure converſation which is or ought to be with feare. Howbeit ſuch hath beene the coldnes of a manie in this kind, the averſenes of others vnleſſe there be Sermons to, the connivence even of Paſtors, I, and ſoothing their Flocke in this ſin, that the People who by their converſatiō ſhould haue converted others vnto vs, are themſelues now in theſe daies cōverted vnto them, and a many of vs the Miniſters that hoaped of much intereſt of bringing ſouls vnto God, ſtand nowe in doubte of looſing the verie Etiam de ſorte nunc venio in dubium miſer, Terent. A delp • . Act. 2 ſc. 2. principall it ſelfe. I pray God 2. Tim. 4. 16. ſaith the Apoſtle in a caſe of leſſe moment, that it may not be laid to their charge. Doubtleſſe among all the overſights to be laide to the charge of vs Proteſtants, this of frequēting Gods houſe no better is not the leaſt, eſpecially
nowe in theſe times when the Lorde our God hath done ſo miraculo • ſlie ſo much for vs, and when his honour (as it were) lies at the ſtake, and the fruit that wee bring forth makes his name (I would I might not ſay) blaſphemed among the Papiſts.

The conſideration hereof Right deare and dearely Beloved Chriſtians, hath cauſed me as at the firſt to preach theſe two Sermons, the one to the Vniverſity, the other to your ſelues: ſo nowe to ſet them forth only and wholy to your ſelues, that as one of them was the very firſt Sermon that ever I preached vnto you ſince I came to be your Paſtor, ſo it might remaine vnto you for ever as a teſtimony of my care of you, and not periſh with me when I am gone as did a many good words in this kinde with my worthy Predeceſſor Mr Wharton.

Were this your Pariſh of that nature that others be, & the Pulpit not
ſo often, and neceſſarily to be ſupplyed by the Vniverſity as it is, perhaps I would ſpeake thence vnto you more often then I doe, but ſince I cannot what I would, I will now do what I can, even preach vnto you Evangelizo manu & ſcriptione Raynold. de Rom. Eccleſ. Idol Epiſt, ad Comit. Eſſex. by writing, and it grieveth me not (as Phil. 3. 1. ſpeaks the Apoſtle) to write the ſame things to you, and for you it is a ſure thing.

When our Saviour was riſen againe from the dead and Mary Magdalen, and the other Mary came to ſee the ſepulchre, & by reaſon of the Angels countenance that had deſcended from heaven, it ſhoulde ſeeme they were ſome what frighted, Feare ye not Mat. 28. 5 ſaith the Angell, for I know that ye ſeeke Ieſus which was crueified: he is not here for he is riſen, as he ſaid, Come ſee the place where the Lord was laid, And go quickly, and tell his Diſciples that hee is riſen from the dead: and behold hee goeth before you into G • lile: there ye ſhall ſee him: lo I haue told you. I doubt not
Beloved, a many of you are as deſirous to find Ieſus as ever thoſe womē were, eſpecially in this age when ſo many Romiſh Sable Catholicks, ſo many Engliſh Browne Schiſmatrickes ſo verefie our Saviours words, Mark. 13. 21. Lo here is Chriſt or lo he is there, as it is in Saint Marks Goſpell. I know I am not fit to be likened to the Angell, but yet may I ſay what did the Angell Lo I haue told you, and as our Saviour Mat. 11. 14. ſaid in another caſe of Iohn the Baptiſt, And if ye will receiue it, this is Elias: ſo I in this caſe, And if ye will receiue it, this is the truth I haue here delivered in theſe Sermons.

Wherefore as the Prophet Eſay Eſay. 30. 21. ſaid to the Iewes, Th •• e eares ſhall heare a word behind thee, ſaying, This is the way walke yee in it, whe thou turneſt to the right hand, and when thou turneſt to the left: ſo aſſure your ſelues that now in this Age when there is ſo much turning on the Right Hand, and
on the Left, this is the Word your cares haue heard, and I ingenuouſly profeſſe that after ſo many yeares ſpent in this famous Vniverſitie in reading Olde and New writers (you knowe whoſe Mat. 13. 15. precept it was) if either of the other waies, or any other had appeared vnto me better, for the better directing of your Soules, or doubtleſſe I would haue proclaimed it to you vpon the houſe top, hauing had ſo many opportunities, or I would at leaſtwiſe at this time haue vtterly abſtained from printing This: a labour (beleeue me) not the leaſt, and now as the world goeth not ſo neceſſarily to be vndertaken.

J had purpoſed to haue put you in mind, of the place of aboad God hath given you, even in the eye of this Vniverſitie (the Vniverſitie the eye of the Land) as though his meaning were you ſhould be examples to all about you, how they alſo like you ſhould
frequent his Houſe: of Church-Service and of Sermons how they are both (if well performed) like Rahel, & Leah (but Leah without a blemiſh) which twaine did build the houſe of Iſrael and multiplied the heires of the promiſed land: of being to be as loath to looſe the one at any time whatſoever, as a many are or ſeeme to be, to looſe the other, the profit being incomparable that accreweth vnto vs by either: of being much more hard to Pray, then it is to heare a Sermon, and therefore how it behoveth vs to come the oftner to ſhew our willingneſſe to vndergoe the greater paines in Gods Service: but I am now, even very Octob. 15. 1612. now, ſurpriſed with the newes of her death, who was vnto me in her life the only Iewel of this world. I had thought that Shee alſo ſhould haue had the pervſing of theſe Sermons, and haue ſeene in St Anſtens Mother (twiſe mentioned in the former
of them) the true ſimilitude of he • ſelfe. But God hath now diſpoſed otherwiſe, and given her the place already, which this Booke would but haue guided and directed her vnto, and well am I worthy to looſe the benefit of ſo good a Reader as Shee would haue beene, who haue ſuffred it ſo long to lie hidden by me as it hath. O my deare and worthy Mother what ſhall I ſay concerning thee? I might ſay of thee as Mu • icbri babitu, vnili fide, anili ſecuritate, materna charitate, chriſtiana pietate. Aug. Confeſl. 9. c, 4. St Auſten of his Mother, Thou wert of a womanly carriage but of a manly faith, thou wert fraught with an aged tranquillitie of mind, with motherly loue and Chriſtian affection. I might ſay of thee as Nazianzen of his Nazian Epitaph. Patris. Mother: As the Sunne beames are faire and cleere in the morning and grow brighter and warmer towards noone, even ſo my Fathers wife, ſhewing forth the pleaſant firſt fruits of godlineſſe at the beginning, afterwardes ſhined out with greater light. I might
ſay of thee as did St O vera mater, adamante fortier, me • e dulcior, flore fragrantior Am broſ. de Iacob. & vita beata. l. 2. c. 12. Ambroſe of the Mother in the Machabees, O trueſt Mother, ſtronger then Adamant, ſweeter then Hony, more fragrant then the Roſe. But I will now ſay nothing of thee, only this will I ſay of my ſelfe, I that haue ſaid ſo much vpon the ſeaven & twentith Pſalme the fourth verſe, the ſubiect of this booke: muſt turne me now vnto another Text, and meditate another while vpon the I went heavily as one that mourneth for his Mother. Pſ. 35. 14. fiue & thirty Pſalme the foureteenth verſe, the proiect perhaps of another book.

Pardon me Beloved if I haue as you ſee thus left you a while, & paid this tribute of theſe few lines to the true Soveraigne of my Loue, I now come vnto you againe, and ſpeake againe vnto you but in that which heareafter followeth, and which in part you haue heard already, in part you ſhall now heare.

closer.signed:
Your no leſſe loving, then
loved Paſtor. IOHN DAY.

div.head: DAVIDS DESIRE to goe to Church.
div.p:
IT is 2. Sam. 7. •
recorded of king David, Right Worſh: Men, Fathers, & Brethren, beloved in our Lord & Saviour, that when he ſate in his owne houſe, and the Lord had given him reſt frō all his enemies round about him, how he deſired as S. Stephen ſpeaketh Acts the ſeaventh, at the ſix & fortith verſe, that he might find a tabernacle for the God of Iacob. I will relate it to you in Davids words, Lord ſaith Pſ. 132. 1. David, or whoſoever els was the author of that Pſalme, Lord ſaith he, remember David, and all his trouble: how he ſware vnto the Lord and vowed a vow vnto the Almightie God of Iacob, I will not come within the tabernacle of
my houſe, nor climbe vp into my bed, I will not ſuffer mine eies to ſleepe, no • mine eie lids to ſlūber, nether the temples of my head to take any reſt, vntill I find out a place for the temple of the Lord, an habitation for the mighty God of Iacob. All this in the ſecond of Samuel the ſeaventh chapter and ſecond verſe, is thus epitomiſed: The king ſaid vnto Nathan the Prophet, Behold now, I dwell in a houſe of Cedar trees, and the Arke of God remaineth within the curtaines. His meaning was that ſince al fel out ſo favourably, with ſuch correſpondence to his deſires, ſince hee had ſo much reſt from al his enemies, & God was the author of all this, he would now be gratefull againe to that God, not ſo much in words which are but winde, as in very truth and real deeds, ſuch as might be teſtimonies thereof both to the time then preſent, and to after ages that were to come. Beholde now, I dwell in a houſe of Cedar trees and
the Arke of God remaineth within the curtaines. It was as if he had ſaid, God hath beſtowed a houſe on me, I will beſtow a houſe on him too, hee hath given me reſt from all mine enimies, I will giue him a kind of reſt too, hee ſhall not be from 1. Chron. 17. 5. tent to tent, and from habitation to habitation as hee hath been hetherto. A princely mind and meditation, a reſolution fit for him who was to bee the man after Gods owne heart▪ as Samuel the ProphetSam. 13. 14. avouched of him.

The former part of this day now newly ſpent and gon, hath by the ſilver tongue of one of the chiefeſt & M. D Riues Warden of New College ſweeteſt ſingers in this our Iſrael put vs in mind of like benefits receaved on our parts from God aboue: of ſetting at home here in our owne houſes, every of vs vnder our owne vine: of a ſingular reſt given vnto vs from all our enimies round about vs. This day▪ this very day, it was more
then miraculous that God did for vs, it was in truth a heap of miracles, as firſt the preſerving of our bodies and goods, ſecondly the prolonging of our liues, thirdly the ſaving of our whole Realme, fourthly the protection of true Religion, and all theſe then and at that time when ſafetie it ſelfe might ſafely haue ſworn that ſhe for her part could not haue ſaued vs. David on a time neere to danger ſpake moſt ſignificantly when ſpeaking of it vnto Ionathan, As the Lord liveth, & as thy ſoule liveth 1. Sā. 20. 3 ſaith he, there is but a ſtep betweene me and death. Anacharſis the Scithian ſpeaking of thoſe that ſayled by ſea, and hearing that a ſhip was but foure fingers thicke at the moſt, then are there but foure fingers, Diog. Laert tit. in Anach ſaith he, betweene them and death. At another time being demaunded who were more in number the living or the dead: tell me firſt, Diog. Laert Ib. quoth hee, among whether of them you reckon thoſe
that travell by ſea: his meaning was that howſoever they ſeeme to liue, to moue, and haue a being, yet they might with good congruitie bee accounted even for dead, for nothing ſo ful of caſualties as the Nihil tam capax fortuitorum quàm mare. Tacit. Annal. l. 14. ſea and that in the turning of a hand.

Vpon how tickliſh tearmes wee ſtood this very day when time Novemb. 5 1605 was, the more we muſe of it the more we may, & how might al & every of theſe ſpeeches here rehearſed haue bin verified of vs. A ſtep of that wretched miſcreant might irrecoverably haue laid all our honour in the duſt, a very finger of his might haue done it. Our adverſaries abroad that ſaw the caſe wherein wee ſtood, how did they newſe it to one another that wee might bee now accounted dead. A Diſcourſe of this late intended treaſon. Fol. F. 3. Terrible Blow was now at hand, we had all and every of vs but one necke, and that neck of ours was now on the block. The horror wherof
if we would conceiue let vs but imagine another Fauks in ſome one of the vaults here abouts, as many barrels, as much powder, and that which then matched both barrels and powder. Doubtleſſe we are never better affected vnto God thē whē we pray: we are now in the houſe of praier, & prayer you know was the laſt, the verie laſt thing we did, yet ſhould we all of vs now miſcarry and in this very in ſtant of time be ſnatcht out of the world and haue the ſudden death of thoſe of whō El • hu in Iob Iob. 34. 20. Tremel. ſpeaketh momento moriuntur, they are gone in a trice, or as ſpeaketh the 1. Cor. 15 52. Apoſtle S. Paule, In momento, inictu oculi, in a moment in the twinckling of an • i • , how vnpreparedly might we all goe to appeare before that throne where this day we ſhould receiue everie of vs our laſt doome. And yet wee are but a handful to the See the B. of Lin • . Anſwer to a nameles Cathol. p▪ 360. 361. houſe ful of thē that ſhould haue miſcarried, and yet
they though well affected no doubt as men in civill affaires might bee, yet ſomewhat perhaps behind our ſelues in reſpect of the ſoules buſineſſe wee are about.

But it is not nowe of this point I point now to ſpeake, my intent and purpoſe is to ſpeake of the Thankefulneſſe and Gratitude wee are to performe to God for this, not ſo much in words which are but winde, as in very truth and real deeds, ſuch as may be teſtimonies thereof both to theſe times now preſent, and to after ages that are to come. What hath the Lord preſerved our honor? We will alſo preſerue his. Hath he made our houſholds like Pſ 107. 4▪ flocks of ſheep? We will endevour in like manner to furniſh alſo his houſe: be it early, bee it late, it ſhall not for our partes, be ſo naked as it hath beene hetherto.

To the producing of which effect in every of vs here preſent, be wee of
